text: Piwo skonsumowane. Ocena na podstawie retrospekcji w celu uzupełnienia profilu. Czekolada, kawa, sos sojowy, wędzona śliwka w aromacie. W smaku gładkie, kremowe, a przy tym palone. Ciemne owoce w typie wiśni i śliwki, gorzka czekolada, melasa, ciut lukrecji.
Bottle at Brewers Ball Dallas. Pours a very dark brown with small beige head that lasts. The aroma is roast and smoke. Medium body, roast, dark chocolate, smoke finish, very good.
Bottle. Color black with almost no head. Aroma roasted, malt, some smoke, chocolate. Taste sweet, roasted, chocolate, some bitterness, some smoke.

On tap at Ginger Man way back in 2013. Pours a deep black with a offwhite head that leaves good lacing. Nose is of burnt grains, smoke and some booze. Taste is of coffee and other roasted malt derivations and green hops. Moderately bitter and it doesnt feel sweet at all. Body is full, carbonation moderate and mouthfeel quite smooth. Alcohol is not as prominent as the nose would indicate. A really nice smoked baltic porter, not a sweet mess like so many others!
Bottle @ home ... trade from Fullobs... thx my friend.... It pours black with a small light brown head.... smokey, roasted malt. coffee, it got this freshness and roasty ...that I love!

0,33l fles gedeeld met Nikos. Zwart bier met een bruine schuimkraag die snel slinkt. Geur en smaak vallen wat tegen, de rook is moeilijk terug te vinden, de donkere mout is ook meer op de achtergrond. Biertje is vooral erg zoet. Niet vies maar ook zeker geen uitblinker.
Amazing mix of malts and hops. Really black in color. Warming beer with great malty taste. full body works just great for this porter.
12 oz bottle from 2011 notes. Pours dark brown to black in color with a medium sized beige head. The aroma and flavor had roasted malt, dark chocolate, earth, char and a nice smoked character.

Botella de 33 cl en cimmeria en octubre de 2012. Color negro intenso. Bastante buena smoked baltic porter con 7 vol y un cuerpo medio fácil de beber. Ligeros sabores quemados y ahumados con algo de chocolates y cacao. Bastante buena y para repetir sin problemas.
bottle. black with small head. dry porter with big roasty malt and coffee bitterness.

Bottle poured black hue w/ small tan head and lacing. Moderate smokey aromas. Initial flavor is light sweet w/ a light bitter finish. Tastes are dark roasted malts and smoke. Full bodied, creamy mouthfeel and soft carbonation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Porter complessa e intrigante, con note di cioccolato, espresso, malti tostati, una leggera sfumatura di frutta scura secca e un amaro finale, esaltato nel finale piuttosto secco. Veramente esntusiasmante!
Sehr dunkelbraunes Bier mit geringer Schaumkrone. Geruch sehr röstmalzig, Kaffee, alkoholisch. Geschmack röstmalzig schokoladig, Kaffee, alkoholisch
Bottle. Pours black with tan head. Aromas of roast, touch of chocolate. Has medium to full body, good roast, dry. Really nice. Good beer.

Tap at brewery. Pours opaque black with fizzy tan head. Aroma is roasted and chocolate malts, light ash, light spice, and some earthy notes. Flavor is dry roast malts forward with chocolate, espresso, dried dark fruit, and light ashy bitterness; dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2014 Draft at the brewery. Pours black with a thick, fizzy tan head. Tastes like coffee, semi-sweet chocolate, and pretty bready. Medium body and low carbonation. Smells like cocoa, grains, and light smoke.

Bottle at home (bottled 01/25/11). Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma of smoke, roasted malts, and dark chocolate. Full, creamy, taste of chocolate and malts. A very nice beer, too bad it is retired.
bottle from trade to glass. no smoke in aroma for me, much roasted flavor and some chocolate. dark pour with nice dark brown/beige head. light sweetness and bitter. very smooth; velvety nice brew.

Beautiful pour. Beer is almost black but picks up just enough light for highlights. Very thin tan head on top, but has great lacing in the glass. On the nose is fresh baked dark German bread with wisps of peat smoke drifting through it. Very deep and roasty. Like the aroma, dark bread hits the tounge first washing down the middle. Roasted coffee bitterness grabs the sides of the tounge. The beer is thick and chewy on the palate, coating the tounge in a malty wash. Light bubbles of carbonation push the breadness back to end in a smoky finnish. Peat smoke lingers after the swallow.

Pour on tap at Rackhouse, dark black pour with tan head, aroma brought notes of smoke, roast, coffee, nice dark chocolate in there, hints of earth in there as well, nice dark fruits come through as well. Taste is a nice mix of dark chocolate, roast, coffee, into smoke, spice notes, slight dark fruit, finishing bitter, dry.

12 oz bottle from Evergreen Discount. Black with a small brown head and minimal lacing. The aroma is roasted/burnt malts, light smoke, dark chocolate, licorice and caramel. Similar flavor with a medium body and a lingering smoky finish. Very nice, my favorite Left Hand beer to date. Are we sure this is retired? Thats too bad.

Bottled. Pours deep brown with a large, creamy and lacing beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and smoked notes. Sweet flavor that ends up more dry and with bitter notes. Medium bodied, oily to creamy text. And flat carb. An excellent porter.
Bottle. This is a really nice brew with lots of character and flavor. worth getting.

1/02/2011: Left Hand Fade to Black... Aroma: Didnt know that this beer changed from the last time I had it, so the aroma was quite a surprise at first. I love the meaty smoke laced with heavily caramelized malts and hints of chocolate. Appearance: Very dark brown, nearly black; mostly opaque; repestable tan-colored head. Flavor: Delicious blend of smoked meat, dark chocolate, roasted and caramelized malts with just the right amount of residual sweetness, roasted coffee beans and some cacao nibs in the finish mingled with some charred wood/charcoal flavors; FANTASTIC synergy of flavors! Palate: Medium-full body; slightly thick and creamy on the tongue; nice body that supports the flavors well. Overall: Very fine beer; more smoke is always appreciated, but this has just enough smokiness to make me happy and not offend smoked beer newbies too badly...
16 fl. oz. draught enjoyed at Peachs in Yellow Springs, Ohio. Rating #333 for this beer.
Creamy dark beer. Some notes of slice, chocolate and I think dark/dried fruits. Not aggresive, but quite modest and gentle.

zwart, met minimale bruine kraag, schenkt als motorolie
aroma: hout, moutig, chocolade, toffee, koffie, caramout, gebrande mouten
smaken: medium zoet, licht bitter, sterk alcoholisch, geroosterde en caramouten, caramel, gerookt nat hout, lichte turf
medium body, romig, laag co2, 
Dit bier Moet eerst even opwarmen, niet super maar ook niet echt slecht. 
ik zou er niet meer van inslaan

Solid. Solid. Solid. Such a reliable beer. Refreshing with a hint (but not too much) of roasted malts, not too thick like some porters.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: chocolate, grass, citrus, smoke, smoke, 
Appearance: black, 
Taste: light sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: full body, creamy, long finish, 
Overall: Tremenda porter, super ahumada, chocolate, muy bien equilibrada. Algo de lupulo citrico en un momento del trago. 100% repetible.

A - Pours pitch black with a 1 finger tan head that holds good retention. Diamond patterns of lacing.

S - Roasted coffee beans, rich chocolate, lots of malty lactose, campfire smoke.

T - Smoked meat, wood, and chocolate dominate. Dark ground coffee, bittering hops, subtle alcohol, black pepper, with a little sourness mixed in. Sweetness is in there to balance out the savory smoke. Finishes with small smokey hop bite.

M - Full bodied with low carbonation, very silky.

Fantastic! A well constructed smoked Baltic Porter. This provides exactly what youd expect. Full on smoke mixed with the Baltic style. Its porter nirvana! Great mix of sweet, sour, and bitter. One of the best Ive had from this brewery.

Serving type: bottle

04-20-2011

3/IV/13 - 12Fl. Oz. bottle from Biernavigatie (webshop, NL) @ home - bottled: I/25/11 (2013-300)  
Clear dark brown beer, small creamy beige to brown head, unstable, bit adhesive. Aroma: mocha, dark caramel, cocoa powder, some dried fruits, bit sugary, coffee. MF: soft carbon, medium to full body. Taste: dark chocolate, mocha, smoky notes, bit sour, bready, sweet caramel. Aftertaste: gentle smoke flavours, caramel, lots of alcohol warming the throat, bitter hops, coffee, ripe banana, dark chocolate.
Okay...i have to use the amount of characters that Ratebeer says so....bit plain...more like a desert...enough ratebeeer :-)

Black with ruby lowlights and a creamy thin brown crown that sticks around.  Aroma of smoke, roasted malt, light chocolate, campfire and smoked meats.  Taste is weird with smoked malts, light coffee, mild peat and a hint of chocolate.  Semi sweet and a touch gritty.
Bottle 0.335l. Colour is black with small brownish head. Aromas and flavours are smoke, roastiness, coffee, chocolate and some malts.

It is undeniably a really good beer.   Top notch.  Just happens to not be my favorite.  Really smoky to me and finishes quite bitter.  Also get coffee, chocolate, earthiness......All warming on a cold night in Ocracoke. Pours porter dark with a thin head that doesnt stick.
Bottle from Flanders Ned. Smoked baltic porter nails it. Starts with licorice. Thick black pour. Smoke and roast aroma.  Roast to near burnt. Big big mouthfeel.  Very tasty and lovely drinkability.
en botella.negra con fina espuma,aromas malta ahumada.cuerpo medio.un poco salada.
Silky jet black pour with a thin beige cap. Aroma: roast malt, smoky peat, chocolate, coffee. Taste: Chocolate, malt, hops, dark fruit, liquorice, smoky heat. Low carbonation and quite moreish.

Poured dark black and fairly viscous with a frothy tan head which quickly dissipated. Aroma of heavy roasted coffee malt. Flavour of smooth chocolate malt and a surprisingly mild creamy mouthfeel. Sweet chocolate aftertaste.

Bottle at the Brew Dock, Dublin. Appearance: Jet black, small brown head. Aroma: Rich chocolate, coffee, cream, liquorice, quite roasty, good deal of smoke. Smells great. Flavour: Soft mouthfeel, creamy, lots of coffee, malty with a lot of rich chocolate, delicate coffee finish. Quite lovely.

Draught at the brewery, on October 10, 2012Black color, light brown head. Sweet, molasses, roasted, coffee, caramel, fudge taste. Sweet, coffee aftertaste. Medium mouthfeel, medium high dry bitterness. Sweet, roasted scent.
Dark brown pour, almost black, tan head.  This brew is smokey, malty, chocolatey and some dark fruit flavors.  Creamy feel and enjoyable.

bottle    pours almost black with tan head that becomes a thin film . aroma is mild notes of coffee , toasted malt , esters . taste reflects the aroma  with toasted motes prominent . low carbonation gives a good mouthfeel . Alcohol level is managed well  - long finish with lingering warmth in the throat

bottles were delivered mixed up, thought i had 2 3s but 1 seemes to be a 2.
this is sweet, chocolaty, soft and very good drinkable. stout-ish taste, realy like it ! nothing realy extreme, yet very good indeed, not over the top in anything...

thx. to Kraddel for sharing // 33 cl. bottle split // black with a lovely mocha head, sinking away rather fast // smell is mocha ice cream, milk chocolate, creamy, vanilla blended with roast and reasonably meaty, gravy // taste is similar sweeter blend of mocha ice cream, some roast creeping up, malty, touches of dark chocolate, milk chocolate vanilla, meatier roast, gravy. // creamy, smooth // interesting, neat

355 ml bottle. Bottled 01/25/12. From bierzwerg.de.
Black colour with small tan head.
Aroma is roasted malt, ash, mild sweetness and liquorice.
Flavour is roasted malt but even more sweet sugary malt with some notes of liquorice and anise. Not very much Baltic Porter but tasty anyway. Smooth.

(Bottle, 0.355 l - bottled on 25.01.2012, courtesy of rosenbergh, 20120721) The beer poured black. Its head was medium sized and lightly brown. Aroma had roasted malts, liquorice and dark chocolate. Palate was medium bodied with medium carbonation. Flavours were roasted malts, chocolate, smoke, liquorice, mildly sweetness and lowish bitterness. Aftertaste was roasty and bitter. Nice and balanced roasty brew.

Bottle from Ølbaren, CopenhagenBlack color, with medium sized brownish creamy head. Mild aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, smoke, cream. Medium body strength; quite powerful roasted malt and dark chocolate flavor; the smoke is only hinted, or at least covered; the final is weaker. Quite strong bitterness.Ordinary; rich in chocolate, poor in smoke.

Bottled. More or less black colour with a very small beigeish brown head. Aroma is mild smoked wet wooden notes, some roasted malts, liquorice as well as mild bready and floral notes. Flavour is mild smoke, some roasted malts, liquorice, quite earthy and herbal as well. Mild not-too-sweet ripe fruityness too. Smoked wooden aftertaste.

Looks nice, poured into a goblet, black as night and virtually no head.

Muted smoke, a sweet malty smell, and burnt malt on the nose.

Solid porter. Lots of roasted malt and a tinge of burnt malt quickly followed by sweet malt nicely placed at the end.

Soft and creamy, light carbonation... sublime mouthfeel.

Overall a great beer. The smoke is subtle, just like "smoked" is written on the bottle. I like that.

Pours black with a dark tan head.
Scent is chocolate, dark fruit sweetness at first......smoke.
Taste is a creamy chocolate...roasted malt and a nice smoky burn.
From a left-hand craft-pack of indeterminate age....must have been long enough, because its quite smooth. The charcoal/smoke just keeps building as it goes.
Very good......
Bottle.  Dark chocolate/coffee malt and light charcoal aroma.  Opaque black-brown color with moderate head.  Creamy dark chocolate malt and lightly bitter herbal hops flavor.  Very nice.

Poured into a pint glass. Black with a one finger mocha head with nice lacing. Aroma of creamy, smokey, chocolatey malts. Taste follows nose, nice balance of all flavors. The mouthfeel is the only place where Im disappointed, way to thin, even for a porter, just way too watery. Overall not bad, above mediocre.

Year old bottle. Pours frothy black with creamy head. Smell is of burnt wood, taste is über smokey. Builds with age? Maybe, I failed science and home ec. Tasty if you like smoke.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 fl oz bottle pickerd up @Kihoskh, København. Cellared for a year. A creamy light choco-colored head, upon an opaque black body. Milky chocolate aroma, along with gently roasted dark malts. Hints of smoke, creamed caramel and vanilla. Medium to full body. Smooth and thick in the mouth. Rounded, well roasted dark malts with subtle tar and smoke. Also   some milky tones. Soft creamy dark chocolate finish. A really nice one.
12oz bottle from Bitter Virtue, Southampton. Pours completely black with a small tan head, which fades away quickly. Delicious smokey flavour.

Originally reviewed: 12/11/11. Glad to see a bottle of this still on the shelf at my local haunt, as I missed it when it first came out. 12oz bottle poured into a pint glass. 

Pours a dark black with absolutely no head at all. Not even the slightest bit of lace on the edge. Suspicious. Ive seen more foam on a Coke. Light smoky aromas in the nose, roasted meats, sweet malts. The body is a touch thin. Id prefer a bit more heft. A nice smoky flavor wraps this beer up nicely. Faint chocolate in there, but the char and smoke qualities win out. Slightest sweet kiss on the finish. Not bad.
Really good. I have no idea what a Baltic Porter is, and I dont like porter (yet) but this is a peppery wonder. Darkly malty loveliness

Poured deep blackish with 2-finger tan head.  Nose is roasty rauchy black patent malt, molasses, cacao.  Tastes rich, chocolate malty with well integrated rauchy notes, some port and dark fruit, and backup hops giving a complex finish.

Pours dark brown, verging on black with a 1 finger foamy tan head. Aroma of chocolate and roasted malts, some coffee and smokey burnt wood notes. The smoke is much more evident in the taste. Roasted espresso beans and chocolate are mixing it up nicely with dark fruits. The taste is all about the smoke, but not cloyingly so. Very smooth mouthfeel with a good amount of carbonation. Overall, this is a well-balanced and interesting smoked porter.
super flot i glasset, smagen er let dejlig engelsk lakrids, fornemmer ingen eller kun lidt bitterhed... super med megen kort smoke.. Got of mr. . Papsø...

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of Pinball. Pours an opaque black with a light brown head. Sweet roasty vanillaish nose with a subtle touch of smoke. Sweet and slightly salty licorice accents. Medium body, sweet roast, vanilla and tar with a round and warming finish. Not a smoke beer, but a very well made Baltic Porter with a whiff of smoke. 280312

Man, Ive been sitting on this bottle for awhile now. Cant believe this was brewed in 2010. Im a huge fan of Smokejumper, so its a bit of a sin that Ive been waiting this long. Guess it got lost in the back of the beer fridge. Anyway, upon opening it doesnt seem like anything is wrong with the beer. Pour is jet black with a nice tan foam. Foam fades quickly but laces nicely. Beer smells amazing. Spice, smoke, and roast. Some dark chocolate. Smells lush and full. Very lustful smelling beer. Tastes is quite good. Smoke is there but not ridiculous. In fact, everything about this beer seems impeccably balanced. Nice sizzling spice on my tongue for the finish. Maybe not bold enough, but this beer does have some time on it. Quite good. Hope they make it again someday.

Nice and crisp, pretty clean finish. Don't get much of the "pepper" until the after taste. Seems too dark to be a "porter" but still kinda light (not heavy)

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black with thick tan head. Aroma of smoke, dark roasted malt, and a touch of chocolate. Flavor is very smokey with rich dark roasted malt and some chocolate notes, a little sweetness comes through the smoke. Mouth feel is medium-heavy body with medium carbonation. Overall, solid brew!

Bottle. Black as anything, thin tan head which persists. Aromas are like someone set fire to clotted cream, huge meat-smoke and dairy with  with plenty of dark chocolate on the side. Tastes amazing, incredibly balanced chocolate, coffee and vanilla but with that omnipresent salty-smoke which never overpowers. Excellent beer.

(Bottle, Ölbaren, Copenhagen, 16 Feb 2012) Black colour with frothy, pale brown head. Malty, roasted nose with notes of pine needles, black coffee and dark chocolate. Malty, roasted taste with chocolate, coffee, dark bread and a gentle cocoa bitterness in the finish. A touch of peat, but not very smoky. More than medium body, with a rounded, almost creamy, mouthfeel. A certain sweetness lingers throughout. Very nice and well balanced.

Pours a dark oily black. Very little head. Aromas of smoke, cocoa, caramel, milk chocolate, metallic, sour and a little dark fruits. First taste is smokey, spicy and peppery. Different. Some cocoa and milk chocolate notes come through in the middle and finishes with a spicy cream flavor. Mouthfeel is very oily, pretty thin and the pepper lingers. Interesting beer, pretty tasty too.

Bottle: As black as tar, small and stable tanned head, smoke and peat on the otherwise fruity and leathery nose; solid sweet-bitter flavour, pretty soft and pretty full bodied; lingering drier smoky to coffeeish finish, completed by a fruity touch and an illusion of a hoppy bitternesd. Really good

Bottled. The aroma has chocolate, caramel maltiness. Black coloured with a beige, medium head. The taste is light bitter, has caramel and dried fruity malty sweetness, chocolate. Medium body, relative dry finish considering the initial sweetness. Nice.

Black.  Smooth, stout like palate.  Thick.  Very light smoke aroma and flavor.  Rich malt, with charred grain, very much like an imperial stout in that way.  I would like more smoke, and less charred grain, but still a solid beer. Dry, bitter finish.

Pours so dark that, even though it is clear all you see is a small red flame shining through from your light source.  Taste is big - almost a typical big chocolate/coffee stout, except this one has coal smoke just pushing through in the middle.  There is fair bittering in the finish, although I would blame it on bitter chocolate and carbonation before I could readily ID hops.  Overall, a well-done brew.

Almost black with a diminishing dark brown head. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, sweet chocolate and moderate smoky - peat. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and roasted rather bitter finish. Smooth and oily. 140112

Bottle. Dark brown colour with a small light brown head. Roasted aroma with smoke and chocolate. Roasted malt, smoke, dark chocolate, some sweetness and bitterness. Medium-bodied. Quite good, not as smoky as I expected.

12 ounce bottle.
Aroma: smoke, plums, sugary malts
Appearance: solid black with a thin ring of bubbles
Taste: smoke, rich malty porter, chocolate, char
Palate: thick and slightly oily
Overall: A very interesting beer. The smoke is not over powering at all, in fact it balances the thick body and rich maltiness very well.
Bottled.  Black, small beige head. Aroma of chocolate and licorice. Sweet and full bodied with milk cushiony chocolate, tobacco and mild peat. Mild and warming with mid bitter finish.

Bottle from Stirchley Wines, Birmingham. Dense black pour with a thin tan head. Roasted malt, dark fruit, chocolate and smoke in the nose. Smooth, creamy mouthfeel. Flavour was similar to the nose with the smoke not too all-encompassing. Dried out somewhat towards the finish. Im not too fond of this style, but quite enjoyed this.

I did not know Fade to Black was different every year. This one has been hanging out in the fridge for a while, I guess close to a year (bottled 12/07/10). Aroma is smoke, dark fruits, citrus hops and dark caramel. Dark brown color with dark red tinting at the edges, mocha colored smallish head. Thick, viscous mouthfeel initially, but balanced at the finish. Taste is dark fruits, a touch of roast, dark caramel and light smoke. I would like the smoke flavor to be more pronounced.

In short: A moderately smoky porter with a few things I didnt like.  Just ok
How: Bottle 12oz.  Consumed approximately 8 months after first rating.  Was there many batches?  Anyway, at most 8 months old
The look: Black body topped by a large dark beige head that quickly recedes to a small layer of foam
In long: Nose is moderately smoky, nothing overwhelming here, and the smoke has a smoked pork character.  Taste is soft black liquorice candy, some figs, plums, roast, some boiled asparagus, some molasses, some tar.  And of course the smoke which added a strong smoked pull pork flavor to the beer.  Overall not a bad beer but there was a few things that didnt quite worked with me in this beer.  Another ordinary beer from Left Hand.  My love for this brewery knows bounds.
Bottle pours an almost black with a tiny brown head. Scent is smoke and roasted malt with chocolate. Taste is same.

(bottle) pours a reddish black colour with a frothy brown head. aroma of cherries, brown sugar and toasted malts, with some restrained notes of barnyard and smoked ham. flavour is mostly the same, toasted malts and minerally herbal hops in the foreground, very chewy, with a very subdued smokiness and a lingering roasted-bitter milk chocolate finish. medium-bodied with average carbonation.

Bottle at North Bar, Leeds. Extra appearance point for the brilliant bottle art. Pours a dark black (appropriately enough), small but thick tan coloured head. Aroma of spicy hops, smoke/toast, chocolate. Taste is lovely - roasty, toasty, coffee, with a good smoke character and coffee/chocolate flavours. Relatively syrupy mouthfeel. Lovely.

12 oz bottle (from De Bierkoning) at home. Pours an almost black color. Brown head (not much). Aroma is mildly smoky, sweet, milk chocolate (zeg maar koetjesreep), a bit of peat. Flavor is medium sweet with smoky notes. Medium bodied. Finishes with a mild bitterness and some smoke/ash. Really like this.

Bottle from Great Grog. Pours a very dark ruby - brown colour with a thick tan head. Aroma of chocolate, smoked malt, cigar box and caramel. A little smoky flavour also with black pepper, roasty malt, burned toast and coffee also. Moderate carbonation and a slick, oily mouth-feel. Nice lingering chocolate and coffee flavours. Alcohol is present but doesnt overpower. Very nice indeed.

It poured a dark brownish black color with a small creamy off-white head.  The aroma was smoky malt, caramel, & some chocolate.  The taste was of smoky roasted malt, dark chocolate, caramel, some hops, and coffee.  A very decent smoked porter.

23rd September 2011Bottle from Bier Koning. Solo hungover tasting in my hotel room! Very dark brown - black beer. Residual tan head. Mild carbonation in the light semi dry palate. Dark malt that it sweetish and with some molasses. Trace of smoke. A little fruit underneath. Finishes semi dry with some dark toffee - caramel. Interesting beer - intense dark flavours in a light palate.

Pours a clear and dark brown beer with a weak chocolate head. The aroma is malt, roasted, ash and notes of soya. The flavor follows the nose with additional sweetness. The palate is dry with sweetness. Overall an average beer.

Draft at Iron Abbey. Pours a nice black with a white snowy head. Very mild aroma, smokey chocolate notes coming through. Taste builds as you drink it. Reminds me a lot of dry, bitter dark chocolate, almost like baking chocolate. Very dry and thin on the palate, but in a nice way. Easy to drink. I really enjoyed this.

Bottle ,tfs vaiz! Aroma is salty, silty, liquorice, some roasted malt. Its baltic alright. Flavour is deep liqorice, then roasted malt, then some silty molasses, then smoky malt fading to just smoke. Bitter yet sweet yet salty, great balance, great beer.

Bottle. Black pour, thin white head. Aroma is smokey, roasty, meaty and very intense. Flavor is huge smoke, makes me thick of Bamberg. Very nicely integrated with the silky roastedness that resides in this brew next to the smoke. Very decent balance. Amazing brew.
nose is hazel, some oak, alcohol, roasted malt, feel is watery, carb is medium, taste is tobacco, dry hops bite, coffee, weak bile, sweet malt, late medium leaves

Black beer with a beautiful, quite weak and brown head. Aroma is roasted, lots of liquirice, slightly smoky; strong and pleasant aroma. Taste is roasted, slightly smoky, medium bitterness. Quite simple, taste based on strong roastiness, but not too much ash. Full bodied, smooth and pleasant to drink.

Bottled 330ml (BZ, vol. 2)
Opaque black color, good creamy brown head. Roasted aroma of coffee, licorice, smoke (tobacco) and soy sauce. Medium to full bodied. Toasted, rye bready and coffeish flavor, also soy sauce here. Finish is hickory smokey with lingering in the aftertaste. Balanced and quite easy going porter.
Bottle. Clear dark black. Roasty coffee aroma. Strong palate. Medium carbonation. Awesome stuff. Not Bad.
On draft @ 33. Pours Black with a nice tan head. Aroma is roasted malts and a ton of smoke. Flavor is smokey, coffee, chocolate and  molasses. Medium to almost light bodied. Pretty good beer overall.

Bottle 12fl.oz. @ home.Clear dark black colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, light brown head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, burnt, caramel, molasses - brown sugar, smoke. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration, chocolate, licorice, roasted. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20111009]
Thanks benzai for sharing. Pitch black, opague colour with a light brown head. Smells roasty, chocolate, coffee, vanilla and smoked. Tastes smoked, roasty, coffee, chocolate. Full body, great carbo.

Bottle. Very dark brown with medium light brown head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, little smoke and a little liquorice. Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, smoke, medium bitter, little liquorice, hops, coffee and a little meat.
Medium-to-light bodied (I was surprised by that), very dark color and a lot of chocolate and coffee flavor.  It was a little like a cold Starbucks beverage.
Bottle. Dark Brown body with a small light brown head. Aroma is smoke, light cocoa notes, metallic. Flavor is roasted malt, smoke, coffee. Medium carbonation. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Rich fruit, blackcurrant, chocolate and licorice on the nose. Medium bodied, sweet, slight woodsmoke, coffee and gentle astringent finish. Good head retention.
draft... dark black pour, nice thick tan head, good lacing... lighter nose, mostly roast with a bit of chocolate and vanilla... tastes really good, lots of roast but balanced, easy to drink
Bottled 355ml. A lot of tar throughout. Too sweet to my liking though. Good lacework. I prefered the nose. Reminiscent of Fumé du sanglier.
Bottle.Sounds more like an album than a beer.Black  with a medium body and a creamy head.Slightly smokey with a strong lingering aftertaste. Another excellent beer from an American micro.
at peter ring sort øl smagning. Pitch dark, brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, caramel,licorice. Flavor is roasted malts, caramel, charchoal
Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, ash, liquorish and smoke. Flavour is Roasted malt, chocolate, ash, smoke and liquorish. Quite sweet.

From notes: Pours ink-black with a small caramel-colored head.  Smoky aroma with maybe a note of chocolate.  Medium-bodied, mild depth.  Chocolatey, nutty taste, giving way to mild smoke in the finish.  Liked it, but wanted a bit more of the smoke.
Bottle @ home, shared with DutchDrebus. Pitch black, opaque color, small brown head. Smell coffee and roastyness. Taste coffee, roasty, burned malts and some bitter. Nice carbo, medium body.

Black.  Black with a CREAMY tan head that is , well. Creamy!  Even a little cooler than it should be it was sweet and malty.  As it got warmer the smoke appeared and was a nice addition to the flavors.  The beer caressed the inside of your mouth.  The aftertaste of malt and smoke was very good and pleasant!

Smoked Baltic Porter. Bottle from Beets. Pours beautifully. Black with a bronze head. Great malty flavour bolstered by the not overpowering smoky background. Not Rauch at all. Id say that the robust stout notes are enhanced by admission of one more element. Great beer.

Bottle in a hotel room in Amsterdam.
Dark brown coloured with a small beige head.
Roasted aroma of smoke and liquorice.
Roasted flavour of liquorice, smoke and hops.
Smoked and hoppy finish.

(bottle 5/16/11). Black color. Medium tan head. Moderate malty smoke aroma, with light chocolate and roasted malt. Flavor of the same, with light alcohol and light bitterness. Avg duration. Moderate bitter finish with light lasting roastiness. Slick texture. Moderate carbonation. Good lacing.

Bottle. Very dark brown  almost black, average and fully diminishing dark brown head. Moderate to malty and sweetish aroma, roasted malt, some coffee and faint smokiness. Body is medium, malty and sweetish, some roasted malt and coffee, faint smokiness and licorice. Finish is average, malty and sweetish, coffee and some roasted malt, faint smokiness. Porter with lots of coffee  not really a smoked beer/porter.

bottle at home ... deep black ... yhin tan head ... soft smoked roast malt nose .. dark roast ... definite smoke ... solid roast malts ... nice toffee roast ... ok... but really im just not a smoked fan

Very fine dark brown head, pitch black beer. dark smoked nose, fine and delicate smoke and beneath some peat and chocolate.. Fine body and good length. Wellballanced. fruity body and notes of chockolate, melon, pear, and light apricot. Very fine beer.

Bottle, bought @ Vinens Verden, Odense.
Pours deep black with a big, creamy, staying, brown-beige head. Pleasant smoky chocolate aroma, mild roasted. A bit of tar as well. A bit of dark bread. Medium to low carbonation, very nice creamy palate. Flavour has good smoked malts, chocolate, cocoa, a bit of coffee. Again some tar. Great dry bitterness from malts and hops. Nice beer - just like any other smoked should be ;o)

(bottle, 35.5cl) Black coloured hue with a brown and short foamy head. Sweet roast-malty aroma with loads of dark chocolate, liquorice, marzipan, burnt wood and a whiff of smoke. Moderately sweet flavour, medium to full bodied with a creamy carbonation. Mellow roasty malty base with notes of chocolate, liquorice and shy hints of Bamberg smoked malt; moderately sweet roasty and slightly hoppy bitter finish with a lasting aftertaste of liquorice, mocha and caramel. 28.VIII.11
Dark brown pour with a creamy tan head.  Roasty aroma with some smoke and dark fruit. Flavor is roast, chocolate, coffee and fruit.  Very good stuff!

Bottle at home. Pour is unsurprisingly black with a full, creamy dark tan head. Good lacing, slowly fades to a slightly soapy film. Nose is deeply chocolate, with a definite smoke characteristic too. Surprisingly sweet palate, with some roasty malt character and only a very subtle smoke which then grows into a smokey, woody, rich linger. Wow.
Bottle from Vinens Verden. Nice brown head with good duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are roast malt, notes of smoke and wood, chocolate and hops. More stout than smoked.
Smoke, coffee and roasted malts. Very dark, beautiful and full bodied. This is some thick, oily stuff here.

355ml botle.
Pours dark mahogany, cloudy, thin brown head.
Huge, roasted, smokey aroma, chocolate, coffee beans, tar, hops, alcohol, licorice.
Medium sweet, full body, medium bitterness, high CO2.
Complex taste, lots of roasted malts, balanced smokiness, chocolate, espresso coffee, hops, spices. (2011-09-06)
Long, dry finish. Promises much in the aroma, but doesnt really deliver.

Bottle from Bierzwerg. Almost black color with medium beige head. Aroma of smoked malt, caramel, hints of chocolate and raisins. Taste, coffee, chocolate, smoke, caramel with nice long bitter finish. Alcohol is nicely hidden. Excellent.

A solid smoked beer, I thought the volume 1 (I know completely different styles) set the bar for the series high, and this offering was a bit of a let down. That being said, I grabbed a 6 pack and was happy to drink a few and save a few. Very much looking forward to Vol.3.

Bottle from Bierzwerg. Poured black with a thin brown head. Aroma is light smoke, roasted malt and liquirice. Flavor similar, roasted malt, ash, liquirice. Very hard to detect any smoke in flavor. Smooth, slightly sticky mouthfeel. Dryish finish. Very enjoyable, but had expected much more smoke.

355 ml bottle.
Originally rated on 20110728.
Pours pitch black with small lasting head. Aroma is smoke, ham, dark malts, notes of coffee and a bit of licorice and peat. Flavour is smoked ham, salty licorice and roasted malts. Medium-bodied and a slick palate.
4325

36 cl bottle, bottled on 25.01.2011
A bit light aroma is fresh and has some ham-like smoke and some roastiness. Flavour has smoke and salty liquorice. Bitter finish. Good, kind of reminds me of Schlenkerla beers.

355 ml bottle.
Pours a pitch black colour with a brown head. Aroma of roasted and smoked malts, some smoked wood and ham with hops. Quite strong flavour of roasted, smoked malts, smoked wood and ham, licorice bitter hops and some raisins. Full bodied, a bit thin mouthfeel and a long finish of smoked malts and bitter hops. Very tasty, although Id prefer more smoked malts here.

12 oz bottle thanks to 17thfloor. Pours a very nice black with a creamy deep tan head. Aroma a bit roasty malts, dark chocolate, some smoke though it seems fairly subdued. Flavor starts promising, a quick hot of rich cocoa and smoke, but quickly loses that complexity to a basic roast, dark fruitiness and a touch of a candyish character. Finishes surprisingly quick, some chocolate and still roast. Medium to medium full really nice body and a soft but crisp carbonation. There is a lot of promise here, but things fell apart in the flavor.
355ml bottle.  Pours pitch black with a medium, tight head.  Aroma is leathery ham and a little smoke.  Taste has smoked ham to start.  Licorice  and ham in the finish.

Black pour with a thin head.  Pleasantly sweet coffee aroma.  Lots of roasty coffee flavor and some lush sweetness on the back end.  Fairly astringent, but not harsh.  FtB is more porter than rauchbier.  Baltic porter is one of my favorite styles, and this is a really good version of one.  It was moderately priced too, as I recall - I would certainly get this again.

35cl Bottle from De Bierkoning. Black colour, big beige head. Aroma of sweet malts, roasted malts, light smoke, chocolate, light fruity. Flavour is sweet, roasted malts, chocolate, liquorice, sweet light smokey light bitter finish. Medium bodied, slick. Nice.

Dark pour with a brown head. Aroma is smokey. Nice balanced beer. Smoke flavor is prominent but not dominant. Nice roasted malt backbone. Nice smoke aftertaste. Little dry roasted malt flavor comes out as you drink it. OK lacing
Bottle 0,33ltr: Opaque black coloured brew with an subtle smoked touch, taste of roasted malts. Nice beer label too.

12oz bottle. Pours black with a small brown head. Has a nice smoked dark malts tastes and aroma with some cacao, roasted espresso and some dark fruits. Palate is a nice full bodied and nicely carbonated and rich mouth feel. Finish is roasted dark malts some bitter cacao, roasted espresso and dark fruits. The flavors become more pronounced is it warms up. Overall a nice smoked porter
Really dark with a big creamy head. Smelled of caramel, smoke and coffee.  Bitter taste.

[355ml bottle, Appellation Wines, Edinburgh] Dark, viscous pour  very gloopy from the bottle. Thin, off-white head. Quite an acerbic aroma, bitter smoke. Doesnt taste like a rauchbier - milder, sweetness at the end. Mostly bitter, sharp, however - tastes like the dog end of a coffee pot. Not my thing at all [16082011]

[Tap] Pours a very dark brown color with a thin brown head. Good looking lacing. Aroma of charred malts, wood, peat and light campfire smoke. The taste is that of an export stout. Heavy roast and charred malts, burnt toffee, dark chocolate, ash, dark brown sugar and a moderate amount of smoke. Semisweet cocoa and dry malty finish. Nice body and oily mouthfeel. An enjoyable brew!

12 fl oz bottle. Pours dark brown to black with a small chocolate brown head. Aroma is mild smoked and dark roasted malt, light chocolate note. Smoked, dark chocolate, roasted malty and light breadish. Vague sweetness. Ends dark malty, roasted and smooth lingering smoked.

This is really good. The porter comes through along with some chocolate, coffee, caramel  and a good bit of bread and yeast. The pour is almost black with a small tan head. The flavor has all of the aroma with a nice subtle smoke essence in the back ground. Nice dry finish. Good stuff.

Excellent beer! Served with a thick, creamy, fine, light tan head and good lacing. Color is an opaque brown black. Aroma is malt, toffee, roasty, toasty, fire pit. Flavor is a sweet porter with excellent smoke balance. Body is good and carbonation is just a tad light. Finish is like flavor and has good length and balance throuhout. Session beer.

Nice brown head, pitch black colour, smells malts and alcohol. All outlooks of stout are present. The taste is malty and round. Aroma has mostly roasty malts and earthly yeast type things going on. The beer is also a bit sweet, which I consider is a good thing. At the end quite good beer of this category, but not outstanding.
Bottle from Bierkoning. Darkest brown body with huge, tan head. Nose of molasses, caramel and coffee. Quite bitter. Taste is yummy malts, caramel and toffee. Nice bitter touch to it. Enjoyable.

Bottle. High creamy and long lasting brown head. Pitch black body. Perfect. Roasted malt, liquorice, coffee, smoke aroma. Roasted malt flavor with coffree, liquorice, smoke and a fair amount of bitterness. Very well balanced as the alcohol seems just right and well hidden. Low carbonation, long aftertaste.
Bottle shared with Deanso at In De Wildeman.  Pours black with a medium beige head.  Aroma is smoke, malt, wood and coffee.  Flavour is slightly smokey with roasted malt and chocolate.

35cl bottle shared with kermis.
Smokey aroma.  Thin coffee head.  Very dark pour.  Smokey aftertaste.
Bottle @ Odense Summer Tasting, 2011. Pours dark brown with a creamy off white head and lacings. Sweet nose with a touch of caramel, chocolate and Bamberg smoke. Subdued.  Tasty!
Black with a lasting tan head. Aroma of chocolate, licorice, meaty smoke, tar and caramel. Sweet dark flavour of licorice and smoke. Great aroma, but way too sweet

on tap-pours a dissipating tan head with trailing lace and black color.  Aroma is rich dark malt-smoke/molasses/roasty, some earthy hops.  Taste is rich dark malt-smoke/molasses/roasty, secondary earthy hops.  Full body.
dark toasted coffee flavor, strong alcohol trail, smoke is very subtle for a beer advertising smoke...excellent beer
Bottle at home - shared with Mette. Black - offwhite head. Licorice, nice smokey, dry burned, ryebread, light wooden, high malty, coffee, light chocolate. Dry burned finish.

Bottled. A pitch black beer with a dark brown head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt and wood as well as lighter notes of smoke. The flavor is sweet with strong notes of roasted malt combined with medium notes of alcohol, which is felt on the palate too, as well as lighter notes of smoke, leading to a dry, roasted, and alcoholic finish.
Bottle.Black colour with small beige head.Aroma of dark chocolate and coffee,rosted with good smoked mouthfeels and hint of ham and burnt wood.

Bottle on 01/09/2011. Dark black body with a small creamy tan head. Sweet roast and chocolate aroma. Roast, chocolate, and lactose flavor. Medium full body with moderate carbonation. 7/4/7/4/14 - 3.6

Bottle at Wine and Beer Westpark on 01/08/2011. Presumably volume 2. Dark brown body with a small tan head. Roast and chocolate aroma. Smoke and roast flavor with some chocolate. Medium full body with moderate carbonation. 7/4/7/4/14 - 3.6

Dark brown/black color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of smoky malt, caramel, & some chocolate; Flavor of smoky/roasted malt, dark chocolate, caramel, some hops, and coffee; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Overall, pretty decent smoked porter.
Pours syrupy black with not much head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee and smoke. Taste is the same with a fairly bitter finish. I like the smokey edge on this but perhaps slightly too bitter
Nice beer. Lightly smokey. A little roasty. Very drinkable ale, and is priced well.

Bottle. Pours nearly black with a nice frothy cappuccino colored head with good duration. Aromas of chocolate, caramel, roasted malt and smoke. Sweet malty flavor with roasted notes and smoked malt. A bit sweet, but overall a very tasty and well made beer.

33cl bottle. Pours a lovely opaque black with a brown creamy head, some of which hangs around to leave a thin cappuccino layer of lace. The nose has smokiness and creamy chocolate. The taste has more smokiness and dark burnt chocolate. The palate is rich in structure and creamy in texture but would prefer it to clean a bit more on the end. Overall, though, great beer, though I might have preferred this beer if it hadnt been smoked!

Dark black-brown pour into thin tan head that quickly dissipates into a ring of swirling bubbles and fading lacing. Aroma of roasty chocolate malt and nuts. Initial flavor of dark chocolate, roasted caramel malt, and dark brewed coffee that fades into a bitter creamy finish.
Flöska. Pitch black, beige head. Roasted malty and smoke aroma indeed with some chocolate. Good thick mouthfeel. Roasted malt, some smoke, chocolate, good soft bitterness. Tasty brew indeed!

12oz bottle pours deep dark brown with cold murky garnet edges and thin mocha head. The aroma has a mix of crushed and then sun dried plums and figs as well as earthiness, burnt malts and a modest level of bacony smoke. The taste offers up burnt malts that run from front to back along with smooth pork like smoke, chocolate, molasses and a mild level of earthiness in a sea of bold flavor notes. The flavors are tough to really pin down but they do play well together to make a rich brew. It seems a bit short on the earthy and dark fruity ester side for a Baltic Porter.

Bottle from Marys in OK. Pours a very dark black color with a tan colored head. Aroma is dark malts with heavily roasted nose. Slightly smoked but not overly so. Flavor is pretty roasted with a burnt grain taste and beefy flavor. Finish is pretty bitter. Not bad but a bit harsh.

From bottle. Rich molasses and medium smoke aroma, chocolate and some coffee. Rich with a light tang to it. Nice nose to this one. Dark brown-black opaque, with thin light tan lacing head. Medium-heavy body, not quite oily, with medium carbonation. Starts sweet and rich, malty with molasses, smoke, and chocolate. Coffee and roasted malt bitterness. Nutty sweet finish with mild smoke and light tang. Smooth after. Nice smoked porter.
Pitch black pour.  Aroma and taste is similar with very robust roasted/smoked flavors.  Good beer but can be a little burnt tasting.
UPDATED: JUN 19, 2011 My useful rating: Fuckin awesome smoked porter. Good Fuckin shit bro.

Draft @ Taco Mac Sandy Spring, GA. Pours a black color with a small off-white head. Has a roasted malty smokey chocolate and caramel aroma. Roasted malty smoeky flavor. Has a roasted malty smokey chocoalte finish.
Draft at World of Beer.  Great aroma.  Very nice smoky flavor.  Excellent on a cold winter night.
Brown black with caramel colored head.  Relatively sweet as BPs go in both aroma and taste, with relatively mild smoke.  Borders on cloying in terms of sweetness.

12 oz. bottled on January 25, 2011. Purchased from Bruisin. This is a very dark porter with a small dark tan head. No real surprises here, but Left Hand has pulled out something pretty impressive. I dont know if its quite on the level of Smokejumper, but it is damn good. The aroma has lots of espresso and a meaty undertone, unfortunately pure smoke is not the most prominent flavor but there is enough to impart a very hearty, roasty nose on it. The ashy, smoky, roastiness makes this beer excellent. The bittersweet notes of espresso creme and cacao provide excellent complexity. Its good stuff.
Bottle. Im loving this beer. A touch of smoked meat mixes with chocolate on the aroma. A velvet-smooth mouthfeel leads to some soft smokiness thats quickly leveled off with creamy chocolate coffee.

Bottle given to me by a friend. Pitch black pour with a thick light brown head. Rich chocolate aroma with roast and smoke. Hammy flavor up front, but balanced nicely by chocolate, roast, dark fruit and a bitter hop and dark chocolate finish.

Fade to black volume 2. 1/27/11 bottle

Red porter color w a soft ow head.

Burned raisin bread...very mild smoke. Sweet and mellow. Choco AT . 7.5/3/7.5/4/15+

A 12oz bottle from Picks Liquors poured into a shaker. First off, its BLACK. Very dark black with a minimal amount of dark tan head. The smell is strongly malt, coffee and chocolate. Maybe smoke but I cant be sure. Taste is medium bitter. Full bodied with a thick texture, soft carbonation and a long bitter finish. Overall, Im gonna give it a B+. The price is great, but it tastes more like a coffee stout to me than a smoked porter. There is only a slight aftertaste of smoke, barely discernible over the coffee tones. Makes me wish Shiner still made their Smokehaus beer.

Pours a deep tar brown color with a modest sand-colored head. The smoke dominates the aroma, but it is not overpowering. The flavor likewise features a dry, earthy, woodsy smokiness, but there is also a noticeable cocoa character on top of the expected roasty malt base. The texture is quite creamy, with only a fine, muted carbonation that still manages to conceal the alcohol content. Overall, despite the mild character of the smoke, it still dominates the aroma a flavor, making the whole experience feel a bit one-note. That said, this one was still quite enjoyable.
Black with a fizzy tan head. Chocolate burnt coffee and light smoke aroma and taste with a cereal grain finish.

12 oz bottle acquired via trade and shared with massive Metallica fan Tyber. Pours a dark brown with a very light but bubbly tan head and little lacing. Smell is extremely roasty with a light hint of oak and some smoke and caramel. Taste is a lot more smoky, particularly in the finish with quite a bit of roast and caramel and light oak as well. This one is smooth as a babys ass and quite a good drinking experience.
Pours a deep brown with a tan head. Campfire, bacon, and cocoa aroma. Flavor is a heavier bodied version of smoke jumper, really pleasant roast flavors, fruit, chocolate, malt.

A - Pours a dark black color with some hints of brown around the edges and a finger of brown-tanish head. The head fades down to a ring around the glass leaving behind some nice lace spots.

S - Aroma is a mix of deep roasted caramel malts and some oak and smoke. There is a bit of vanilla and chocolate. Also a touch of milk sweetness.

T - Starts off with nice roasted caramel malts and some smoke/oak. There is just a touch of coffee in the background. Through the middle, some chocolate flavors and a bit of vanilla and milk sweetness come through. The finish is a mix of deep roasted caramel and chocolate malts, some oak and vanilla, and some smoke that lingers nicely.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. A touch creamy and the smoke flavor really coats the mouth nicely. The finish leaves a slight dryness that mixes nicely with the smoke.

D - Very drinkable. Nice mix of flavors in a smoked porter here. The smoke flavor is at a nice level compared to the other flavors. Not weak enough to get over-powered, however, it also allows the other flavors to be known.

Dark dark brown, basically black, dark tan foam.  Aroma is lots of bitter roasty malt, licorice, some ashy smoke.  Taste is smokier, dying campfire embers, very woody smoky, some light malt character lingers int he background in the form of coffee, chocolate, licorice.  Nice.

Draft.  Pours a black body with a tan coffee head.   Very smokey beer upfront.  Peat, ash, and campfire like notes.  Roasted and burnt up malts, very smokey with a drying body.   Inky sweetness a hint licorice like.  Chewy and modestly roasty with a drying warmth.  Nice offering.

Bottle @ Blind Pig. Rich, near black pour, medium brown head. Aroma is smoky and briny with hints of wood. Flavours of smoky burnt malt with subtle fruit acids at the back of the palate. Medium to full bodied, finish is dry and woody with low bitterness
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: (12oz bottle).  Pours black with a nice tan head.  Aroma of savory smoke, chocolate, pumpernickel and bacon?  Taste is semi-sweet malts with some roasty bitterness following.  Medium bodied with an oily texture.  Smooth, dry finish.  This is a very nice beer that balances the base beer with the smokiness.  Good job.

Roasted, creosote aroma. Cool label, opaque black beer.  Intially too sweet.  Candied coffee flavor.  An interestingcrispness to the roast bitter and medium heavy body.  Bottle, Capital Ale House, Richmond.

On tap at Crunchys, East Lansing. Deep opaque brown body, thick light brown head. Spicy hops nose with smoke and chocolate. Strong body with dense inky, salty smoke and chocolate. Rich with fair complexity, and pretty much meets expectations.

Black, with a nice beige head that goes quickly. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, smoke, roasted malt, alcohol. Taste is a nice blend of chocolate sweetness, coffee bitterness and a sticky smokiness. Nice medium-full body and full flavor. Smooth. Definitely much better at a warmer temperature.

Served in a Cantillon tulip.

Pours near black with a single-finger light mocha head with pretty good retention and some spotty lacing as it goes down, eventually settling down into a thin collar. The nose has some roasted malt character as well as some nice chocolate and espresso notes with a bit of dark fruit backing. Dark chocolate is the predominant character.

The taste is pretty congruent with the nose, as theres some roast up front followed by some slightly-bitter espresso as well as chocolate, and then finishing up with some dry bitterness. Body is medium with moderate levels of carbonation. No booze is apparent. Very nice beer overall and I definitely prefer it to Volume 1 of the series.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-27-2011

Smoked Porters are always a good choice, so when I found this Smoked BALTIC Porter, I knew I was in for a treat. Great tasting beer. Thick, heavy, rich. This is their 2010 version of the Fade to Black series. Started with a Stout, and taking a step back to Porter. I am not complaining.

Bottle thanks to Sleeping Beauty and Dallas. What a cool description! Pours a dark brown color with a medium beige head. The aroma is roasted malts, chocolate and smoke. A dry eaysygoing brew; roasted malts, chocolate, smooth smoke, mild in some ways quite drinkable. Cocoa. Enjoyable.

Draft on tap at Binnys SL (Chicago, IL). Pours a pitchblack pour, opaque with a creamy light brown head atop, fairly big, dies to a thick decent layer. Aromas are sweet caramel, toffee, touches of smoke and roast, not meaty, more cherrywood with touches of cocoa, sweet sticky malts, dried out roast. Initial is full bodied, offering cherrywood smoked malts, a bit fruity and woody, with touches of sweet caramel, toffee, biscuits, and cocoa. A touch of molasses, with some coffee roast, sweet and heavy with a decent roast and toast that tries to balance it out. Strengths include not letting the Cherrywood get too cloying, an all too common problem I find with that smoked malt. I think the thicker heavier sweet and roast keep it in line, some light to decent bitter roast into the finish, but quite a full and "fireside" beer. Still, here I am drinking it on a 60 degree day. Very nice beer, a bit sweet, the cherrywood is in check.. Id prefer a different smoke, more meaty, and more dominant. BUT, because its cherrywood Im ok with it laying back some more. A solid Imp Porter.. A bit sweet but nice.

12oz bottle shared by Dallas and Bonnie, thanks 
Appearance: Dark brown with a medium sized tan head and some lacing 
Aroma: Woody, smokey and toasted malts 
Taste: Woody, smoke,  toasted malts and toffee 
Very nice, not overly smoke, easy to drink.

Pours a dark opaque, with light brownish foaming head(I always love that on porters).  Aroma is heavy of smoke and malt.  Taste has light hop front, then heavy malt, with the smoke finishing the taste. Palate is medium body, soft carbonation with a long finish. This might be one of my more favorite smoked beers, as the smokiness is there but not killing me. Really enjoyable.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a nonic pint glass. Bottled on 1/25/11 printed on bottle.

Appearance: Pours a motor oil black with a 1 finger thick and creamy dark tan head which dissipates somewhat quickly. Decent lacing.

Smell: Dark roasted malt, milk chocolate, molasses and coffee. 

Taste: Roasted malt and semisweet chocolate up front followed by coffee and a touch of alcohol in the middle and ending with somewhat bitter hops. There is a definite smokiness throughout. Aftertaste is coffee and burnt toast.

Mouthfeel: Full-bodied and creamy with a decent amount of carbonation. Goes down very smooth.

Drinkability: Good drinkability. This is a sipper that goes down surprisingly easily. Enjoy one or two over the course of an evening and youll be set.

Overall: Very good beer overall. This is my first Baltic Porter and Ill be having more in the future.

Smokey. Pours with a dark hue little head to speak of. Nice aroma of smoked hops. Taste is very smokey, good beer in small amounts. Purchased a growler a week ago and I am slowly working on it. Solid beer. Nowhere near being elite or great.

12 oz bottle. Pours almost black with a tan head. Smoky soy sauce and chocolate nose. The body is actually thinner than I had expected, but crisp and far from light. The taste is somewhat smoky, a little musty, with a bit of sweetness. At 7.8% it is highly drinkable, but I dont think it is quite my style.

On tap at the Dutch Ale house in Saugerties, NY!  This beer pours dark with a 1/2" of tan head.  The aroma is a roasted / smoky with hints of chocolate and coffee. Nice lightly sweet malty flavor.  Almost an oily consistency.  You can taste the 7.8% alcohol in this beer.  Not too thick, but one was enough for me!  Very nice beer!

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2011 Draft today with lunch at the Dutch...conversing with my contractor about the new porch rebuild project.   Mmmmm full bodied and smokey. Malts abound and a bit of formaldehyde appears in a beneficial way.  Tangy.  Dark as a Turkish prison.  Loose spotty drippy lacing.  Uno mas por favor senor.  9/10/11.....In hindsight, the fade to black title and the "porch" rebuild project has nearly killed me.   Residing the house and major structural issues later I can now sit on the porch without the fear of oit falling on me and killing me.

12oz., bottled on 12/7/10, stored in my beer fridge for the majority of the time since then.  Roasty, lightly smoky and sweet aroma, earthy, with notes of dark chocolate, toffee and prune.  Opaque ebony color, head is slight, medium brown and lasting.  Flavor is darkly roasty, sweet, fruity and full of chocolate (devils food?) with an undercurrent of woody smoke in the background throughout, this being far from overwhelming, however, simply making for a pleasant accent.  Very smooth on the palate, drying, with a medium-full body.  Incredibly drinkable for the style.  Enjoyable.

Tasted 1/3/11. 12oz bottle. Bottled on 11 29 10. Opaque with a dark pitch hue. Thick, dense khaki head. Aromas of smoked meats and liquid smoke with mild coffee undertones. Full bodied with a malt dominant palate. Huge smokey flavors with mild citrus undertones. Flavors of toast and fudge covered in Brags Liquid Aminos. Good layered head. This is a quality beer, but it is a bit over in the smoked aspect. Its a nice sipper, but one is enough.

Bottled.  Poured deeper brown with a short, but lovely, deep tan head.  The aroma picked up sweeter campfire smoke and chocolatey malts, with undertones of vanilla and earth.. almost like a woodsy-smoked cake, and that does it for me.  The flavor found well-roasted and near-burnt bakers chocolate and black patent malts at the core.. tasty, but not a lot of standout malt character.. coffee ground-inspired bitterness surrounded.. somewhat warm on the finish, with lots of residual sugars and ashy smoke.  Medium-bodied with moderate-plus carbonation on the palate.. a touch too scratchy, sugary, and salty.. overall a very good brew that Id drink a lot of.

The aroma is smokey but not overly so which bodes well for me since I am not crazy about the style. There is some sweet chocolate in there as well. The appearance is dark brown with a small tan head. The taste is like the aroma with the smoke not overpowering but still present. There is a bit of fruit up front with a bitter finish. The palate is smooth. Overall I am not into this.

Tampa, Fl - Whole Foods - 12 oz bottle. Pours a darker than night black with a tight khaki colored head that clings to the edge of the glass. Aroma is earthy and fresh with some smoked meat accents. Flavor has a hint of smoke, but not overpowering or too meaty. Some licorice comes through, some nice black dirt, and just a hint of chocolate. Thickish, rich mouthfeel. Very flavorful.

12oz bottle 3/24/11 (Courtesy of RSRIZZO) 40° in Dimpled Mug-Pours black with a nice small tan head. Aroma of smoke, chocolate, and vanilla. Taste starts out smokey then the chocolate and vanilla come out and last through out the mouthful. Finishes with more smoke. This full bodied brew is well balanced and hides the ABV fairly well. Nice job.

Pours oily black with a 1 finger, creamy mocha head. Aroma is smoke, coals from last nights fire, musty earth, wet grass, chocolate, burnt coffee, a touch of vanilla and roasted chilies. Flavor is pretty smokey right away, a little chocolate and mild coffee come in soon after, then some roast, char, over done toffee nuts and light grassy and pine hops to finish it out. Palate is medium bodied, creamy on entry, has a moderate, but a little over sharp carbonation and slightly oily, but overall dry finish. Really tasty, at first sip the smoke seems like it will be overwhelming, but it mellows out nicely and lets through some nice malt notes.

Poured from 12oz bottle, pours black with a thin tan head, aroma is of ash with sweet malt, the flavor actually has a nice chocolate profile with a kick of smoke in the finish, decent burnt wood notes, has a very thick mouthfeel, pretty enjoyable.
Smoked, mesquite aroma with hints of coffee.  Pours black.  Roasted coffee flavor with a smoky, smooth finish.

Smoke flavor is a bit muted--not really much of a smoke aroma, actually. Pours a nice, dark brown, almost black with thin head. Smoke is more of an afterthought, a bitter aftertaste. The more I drink, the less it appeals to me.

12 oz bottle, bottled about 2 weeks ago.

It pours a nice dark brownish black with a cascading burnt tan head. The head recedes quickly to globs of lacing.

The smell has root beer, dark fruits, sugar, buttery malts, metal, and some chocolate. No smoke what so ever, is it a joke?

The flavor is a bit more believable. It is fruity and roasty. Still not smokey at all but at least there is a roasted flavor. I think they made a bad decision when they used a Baltic porter rather than an English, or American porter.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-10-2011 05:29:41

20110309   12oz bottle from JC Buy Rite.  Deep, hazy black with small, beige, lasting head.  Aroma is beany, with some coffee, rum cake, and then plenty of rich smoke.  Nicely applied and a good complement to this sturdy strong porter.  Some sweetness mid-palate, but a mild burnt roast comes through to clean that up (if somewhat awkwardly).  Smoke lingers.  None of the acidity that is often found with smoked porters, nor the conflicting American hoppiness.  This is a good interpretation.
Bottle. Pours dark brown/black, with a brown head. Aroma is smoke and roasted malt. Flavor is roasted malt, smoke, and a little bit of fruit.

On tap. Pour is deep brown with a khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, salty leather and light smoke.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of cherry cola. Better than the first one thats for sure.
Tap @ TacoMac, Johns Creek.  Thick black pour.  Aroma of smoked meats, salmon, roasted malts.  Flavor of perfected smoked grains.  A nice grassy hop, mostly smoke, and semi sweet chocolate.

On tap;pour is dark brown, with a tan head. Mild, by the way. Let me just say that while this is a smoked brew, it is on the subdued side. Chocolate, leather, and a touch of campfire, really. The smokiness does pull away as far as the flavor profile goes. Traditional hop profile, cocoa, leather, and the finish leaves something to be desired.

Thick syrupy black pur with a quarter inch beige head.  Smokey, roasted, light dark fruit, lightly sweet malt in the aroma.  Flavor is dominated by the smoke, but it is a medium strength smoke. Some malts throughout and restrained hops. Real nice smoked beer.

12oz bottle from Sams, Durham. Had this very shortly after I tried the Great Divide smoked BP, and I have the same reservations. If you think of this as just a smoked porter, it works quite nicely. But while this brew manages to realize the virtues of designated style a bit more fully - in terms of mouthfeel and lactic flavors - than GD, its not quite fully realized. Enjoyable on its own merits though.

Bottle @ Hotelroom, Denver. Pours black with a ½ inch tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate,smoke raisins,sweet. Taste is roasted malts, bacon, coffee, smoke. Thin to medium body, soft carbonation, lomng roasted smokey finish. Overall a very nice beer, wich gets a +1 for the song reference in the name - seek it out. 080311

Dark brown pour, tan head.  Lots of ham and bacon up front with some back notes of raisins and chocolate.  Flavor is a creamy blend of smoke, chocolate, espresso and dark dried fruits.  Yep, its good.  Wayyyy better than volume 1.

Very dark pour with a nice thick head. Lots of lacing on my glass and the aroma of smoked meats, coffee stick out. Very drinkable smoked beer here with the flavors of roasted malts, smoked meats, and coffee come through.

Perfectly black body with a thin slightly orange tinted tan head. The nose is roasted potatoes and anise. There is also a little bit of coffee. The taste is largely anise with some cocoa. There is also a woody dry note in the finish. This is pretty good.
Plain and simple.. this one tastes like a charbroiled burger..i love it!
pours a dark nearly pitch black color with a dark brown head. the nose is smokey chocolate malts. taste is smoked malts. chocolate upfront with a semi bitter finish. very pleasant porter.

12 oz. bottle, packaged on 12/21/2010.  Pours virtually black at the center with a dark cola-mahogany edge.  A vigorous pour yields just a small, creamy, mocha-khaki head that dissipates quickly.  The wispy film that remains gives tattered, feathery bands of lacing to the glass.  Aromas are well balanced, showing bitter, earthy, dark cacao nibs and roasted coffee in the foreground, with a sweetly smoky overtone and notes of grilled, dark, caramelized fruits.  Theres some plum in there and definitely some blackened fig, along with a good amount of scorched caramel.  The flavor largely mirrors the nose, showing a sharp, bitter chocolate bite with backup coffee roast, and blackened, caramelized sugars.  A bite of anise lends sharpness, while the smoke comes across mainly sweet and slightly nutty.  The palate is smooth and fairly light on carbonation, but it comes across as a bit sugary and sticky on the finish.  It sits pretty heavy and drinks slow.  While fairly tasty and balanced, the weight of the whole package just doesnt thrill me.  Decent brew for the right mood.
This beer is really good. Lots of smoke and roasted malts balanced by a strong hop presence. Some coffee and dark chocolate in the finish. Pretty strong with a medium body.

Pours Black and Thick.  Lots of roasted notes on the nose, with the carbonationy/cardboard smell of a porter.  Definately pungent with some lingering hop notes on the nose.  Mouthfeel is dark and thick.  Taste is huge smoke flavor, like chewing on some embers almost chared flavor.  Aftertaste is largely hops with some roasty/maltyness.  Slightly confused on this one, will need to rerate.  Excellent for the style, however, not sure if I am personally a fan.

Like the Alaskan this tribute never quite eclipses the original, still its a damn fine brew. Nose of smoked ham,  fish and chocolate. Sounds appetizing? Similar flavor in the mouth, the smokiness not as prevalent as the Scherlenka beers,  but still very much dominating. Very solid but missing the special something to make it special.

Bottle. Pours near black with a tan head. Great roasty malt aroma with some light sweet malty and smoky notes. Delicious smoky flavor, with light roasty and sweet malty notes, light burlap/ropey notes, a touch of tabacco. An excellent beer.

This is quite an impressive brew, in all measures.
Pouring from the bottle to the glass, it looks like a beer that means business.....you cant get any closer to black. The cappucino tan head dissipates quickly, leaving an opening for you to gaze into the darkness.
Certainly a smoky malt aroma, hints of some stewed fruits, some browned caramels and a bit of alcohol. Very inviting.
Tastes of dark sugars, giving way to a sweet, smoky body with hints of vanilla.
The finish is like velvet, almost creamy, but still present is the smoky body and a nice warming alcohol slide. 
I really enjoyed this brew. It is wonderfully impressive, but restrainand in all the right areas. Even if youre not a fan of very dark, smoked malt brews, i encourage you to try it....you wont be disappointed.
If I smoked cigars, I would certainly have one with this beer too.

This was a very nice baltic style porter. It poured black with a nice head that lasted. The smell was of wood and smoke. The flavor was smooth with just a bit of smoke flavor and high alcohol. Nice silky mouthfeel and follow. Good beer.

12 oz. bottle at Fireworks.  Its a dark brown pour with a dark, dense head as well.  Lots of roasted malt and pumpernickel notes in the nose.  A touch of smoke as well.  The smoke isnt overpowering and really complements all the dark malt well.  There are some nice burnt notes and coffee in there too.  Well done indeed.

12 ounce bottle.  Pours very dark brown color with a dense 2 finger dark tan head with very good retention that reduces to a lacing cap that leaves some nice lacing.  Aromas of roasted malts, chocolate, burnt wood, and cedar.  Taste of chocolate, roasted malts, smoke, and cedar.  Some very slight bitterness, but not very much on the finish.  Insanely creamy and smooth body, with some smokiness and roasted flavors lingering after the finish.  Medium body and carbonation.  Overall it is a great beer, and one of the few smoked porters I have had, and maybe the best one as well.  I would love to have more of this, it has an great balance of flavors, and one of the best mouthfeels I have had.  Excellent.

12 ounce bottle - $1.89 at Olde Crabapple Bottle Shoppe in Alpharetta, Georgia. Bottled on: 11/11/10.

Appearance: Pours out a black body topped with a medium-sized, tan-head that quietly slips out of existence, leaving behind a skimpy ring.

Smell: The Smoked Baltic Porter smells of chocolate, espresso powder, roasted malts, dark German rye bread, a bit of dark fruitiness, meats cooking over a campfire, and ground-up Whoppers candies.

Taste: Malty tastes of dark chocolate squares, callously burnt sugars, and scorched bread crusts given a generous sip of Italian roast coffee. Charcoal and smoked currants follow. Medium sweetness. Some underlying earthy hop character brings about a slight bitterness. Takes on more dark bready character as it warms. A chew of smoky beer jerky nearing the roasty finish with a bit of tangy Hershey chocolate bar in the aftertaste.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Light creaminess.

Drinkability: Its a good, well-crafted smoky brew. Sufficiently smoky for me, though some might consider it a bit too restrained. A nice addition to the burgeoning FtB series.

Bottle. Pours a dark black color with a foamy beige head. Nose is roasted malts, peat, chocolate. Palate is fluffy and velvety with a nice oily finish. Flavor is chocolate, dark fruits, slick oils, raisins.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of roasted malt, light chocolate, smoke, char, slight tar, and slight smoked wood.  Poured pitch black in color with a medium-sized creamy, tan, rocky, head that diminished except for a think film on top of the beer, and around the edges.  Opaque.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and light to medium bitter.  Tastes of malt, smoke, roasting, light chocolate, slight wood, and Earth.  Medium body.  Slightly thin, lightly dry texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Malt, roast, smoke, light chocolate finish is lightly dry.  7.8%ABV is completely hidden throughout.
Bottle. Dark brown with brown head. Aroma is predominantly malt with roasty notes and some sweet caramel and vanilla along with smoke. Taste is nice lightly sweet malt with a bit of hops. Solid.

(12oz bottle, courtesy of Dixonian)  Pours a dark brown body with a medium beige head.  Aroma of fudge, chocolate, coffee, subtle smoke, and roasted malt.  Flavor of chocolate, roasted malt, and mild smoke.

Bottle with a bottled on date of 1/3/11. Pours with a black body and a tan head. Aromas of bacon, chocolate, molasses, smoke, leather, vanilla and cola. Flavors of bacon, cocoa, and cola. Rich for the ABV. Lively bubbles, a bit thin on the mouth.

Black color/ light brown head. Smoked meat, wood char, deep roast malt aromas. medium bodied. Spicy smoked meat flavors with campfire char, dry dark roast malt, and a mild black licorice herbal sweetness---
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: 12-oz. Black with a loose, wispy, thin tan head. Nice salty, roasty campfire aroma. Creamy medium body, a little undercarbonated. Just a couple more bubbles in this thing and it might could go from really nice to big fat masterpiece. Roast, jerky, campfire, and a bit of salt on the mid-palate. Long campfire finish. Theres only so many ways you can go with smoke, and the base beer under this one isnt trying to do too much, which is super nice for us smoke lovers. Theres no palate shock, theres no lopsidedness to the flavor profile. No flaws in production, none that I can pick up, anyway. Really nice stuff. This ones flirting with greatness for sure.
Black with a khaki head.  Nose is smoke, jerky, bbq, roasted malts, and dry.  Easy palate, flavor is smoke, roasted malts, and pretty much the same as the nose.

Bottle from Oak Tree. Pours a very dark ruddy brown with a 1/4 inch tan head. Aromas of smoke and perhaps dark fruit and coffee. Med body. Flavor is pretty much bacon smoke. Rauch. Undertones of tobacco and leather. Dryish finish.

Bottle; remember the first version being much more pricey.  Poured a dark brown to black with a light brown head.  Aroma of smoked malt, meat, earth, coffee, and chalk.  Flavor showed a bit more restraint, which was a positive.

Bottle to pint glass.

A- Deep, dark black with a tiny tannishhead that disappears almost immediately

S- Smokiness present right away, get a little coffee and chocolate from the roasted malt

T- Smokiness and a tiny bit of bitterness up front, I get more chocolate than coffee in the taste. Not a huge fan of the smoke, but I knew what I was getting myself into.

M- After the initial booze, it is very smooth and creamy, the carbonation is there, but doesnt take away from the smoothness.

D- Good, but not my favorite porter ever. Im not the biggest fan of smoked porters, but this is a good beer for the style. The drinking is slow with this one, not b/c of the alcohol, but b/c of the smokiness.

Serving type: bottle

nice slick and substantial body with a flavor of malt cocoa and coffee light in volume with a generous hint of real smoke. hint of hop that is not much to discern until the burp which has a nice hop burn. good brew but it has been done before. oh yes there is a nice caraway and rye bread taste in the burp and perhaps the finish.
Bottle. Pours black with tan head. Nose of smoked meat, vanilla, BBQ, smoked malt and chocolate. Taste is smoked malt, smoked meat, vanilla and anise. Medium to thick body.
A hard beer to describe.  The smoke does not overpower the beer, its rather subtle, it tastes almost like an Imperial Stout when its really a Baltic Porter.  Hard to describe, but a great beer.

Bottle to glass pilsner.  Pours a dark, dark ruby which appears black with sparse tan head ad not much lacing.  Has a dark roasted nutty flavor.  The scent is distincly almonds.  Its not maltly sweet, nor is it hoppy.  Just a roasted flavor.  Different.
Robust fruity make aroma. Black color with a medium white head. Moderate sweet beginning with a roasted malt finish.

Pours midnight black with a 2 finger creamy light tan head that left spotty lacing.  The nose is smoke, roasty dark chocolate, coffee and lacto.  The taste is burnt malt, ash, smoke, cocoa and bitter coffee in the finish.  Full creamy mouthfeel.  Very good. 7/4/8/5/16

Black in appearance with some slight ruby highlights around the bottom.  A small, thin, tan head with not much size or retention.  Settled to a small ring and just left a scant amount of lacing.  More subdued aromas of coffee and espresso than what I have typically found with the Porters I have tried.  A roasty, smokey type of aroma adds some complexity.  A slight "woody" note that was somewhat pleasant.  Chocolate notes are very mild.  The taste showed more of the burnt, roasted coffee.  Some smoke is present and the chocolate is more up front in the taste.  Its not a sweet chocolate, but a dry, dark chocolate.  I think the taste is solid.  I am enjoying it.  Medium to medium/full mouthfeel.  Somewhat creamy.  Left touches on the palate and it provided a bit of warmth.  I rather liked the taste of this beer.  Nice toucheds of smoke and coffee make this an ok example of a "Smoked" Porter.  I might pick this up again sometime.  Worth a try for sure.
Dark black pour from bottle with a nice foamy off white head.  Taste is dark chocolate and molasses.  Smokey finish.  Nice.

pours very black...thick looking...with a medium sized mocha head.  aroma is roasty with dark fruit and coffee but only the slightest hint of smoke.  flavor has much more smoke than the aroma suggests...very roasty...bit of bakers chocloate...nice hops to balance it out.  mouthfeel is heavy and oily with a lingering very roasty, slightly smoked finish.  pretty nice but not enough smoke as it is billed as a smoked baltic porter.
Jet black with a thin tan head. Aroma of roasted malt. Complex roasted palate with a hint of raisin and burnt sugar. Smoke is just barely perceivable, just the right amount. Very nice.

Very light aroma of smoke/coffee.  Appearance is very dark, delicious looking. The head is minimal, fades quickly, light tan color.  The taste is delicious, well balanced smoky, bbq, porter style.  Not too strong, not too weak, just right.  It is tingly on the palate, simple, yet smooth, with a dry finish, leaving me craving more after every sip.  Overall, this is a dangerously delicious beer.  I am not normally a smoky porter type guy, but this beer is gooooooood!  Great job on the design of the packaging also, it is bad*ss!!

Nose:  The aroma was the only disappointed aspect of this fine brew.  I wanted more roasted malt and coffee, but was lacking

Appearance:  Dark brown with a very small light brown head.

Taste:  Great flavor.  The molasses and roasted malt comes through here.  Coffee and slight vanilla.  Wonderful.

Palate:  Not too heave, Im impressed.  I could drink 2-3 of these.

Overall:  Very impressive Porter.  Up there with Bells Porter, Founders Porter, and Edmund Fitz.

Pours inky, completely black in the glass, with a thin tan head, very fine lasting lacing.  Aromas of BBQ smoke, toffee, sugar cane, bread, grass, and oak.  Medium body, zesty and smooth.  A nice sweet touch up front, some crispness, and just enough dryness in the finish to smooth everything out.  Well balanced.

Pours black with a nice fairly tight tan head giving up some nice lacing on the glass. The aroma is at first very similar to that of a mocha with chocolate and espresso tones but a good bit of smoky ash works its way in there as well, overall it smells powerfully roasty.
