The flavor mirrors much of the coffee, chocolate, and ash that was presented in the aroma. The smoke here is fairly subdued yet on the threshold of too high for a traditional baltic porter. I doubt that the intent here was to try to interpret a traditional baltic porter, and what were given is a beer that is basically a more strongly smoked version of the neo-baltic porters, that I admit to loving quite a bit. As it warms some earthiness presents its self both in a hoppy (leaves & woodyness) and malty (namely soil) sort of way. Add to this a nice hint of plum while maybe some bits of unripe fruit detract but beyond that this is a very tasty beer.
Draught from Against the Grain. Nice and dark, sweet with some smoky roasty coffee flavors.  Good.

On tap at Capones. Poured a deeper brown with an averaged sized off white head. Aromas of smoke, some meatiness, roast, earth, and chocolate. Tastes of smoke, roast, chocolate, earth, and a lighter coffee. Lacing left on the glass.

Black, dense tan head that falls to a half centimeter layer.  Nice smokey creamy chocolate aroma, a touch bacony.  Taste is more of the same, slightly bacony rich smoke with a smooth chocolate layer.  "Velvety" is a word Id use to describe this beer.  Yum.

12 oz. bottle shared at the Big Black Beer Bash 2011. I didnt buy this when it came out and it seems like whatever bottles the STL area got are gone for the most part, so I was glad to see this show up. Pours a deep, dark, opaque brown with a finger-thick beige head. Notes of roasted coffee, smoke, wood, roasted dark malts, dark chocolate, rust, and earth. Medium-bodied, with a smoky, earthy mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Another nice smoked beer from Left Hand.

Pours a beautiful black with a few highlights of brown towards the edge of the glass, nose is sweet and slightly smokey. first sip is full of roasted deliciousness, brown malty flavors permeate quickly in just the right amounts, the smokeyness is just subtle enough and yet still a big part of it.  the finish yields to bitter chocolate and slight coffee flavors. the smokeyness lingers slightly. Just a really great beer.

Bottle. Poured a dark brown color with a small tan head. Aroma was chocolate malts, not nearly as smoky as expected based on what the bottle said. Flavor was what I expect from a nice porter. Touch of dark chocolate, coffee, robust porter. Great brew!

Bottle from kegs and barrels.  Pours black with a thin tan head.  The aromas are chocolate, roasted coffee, malted milk.  The mouthfeel is sticky, bitter and roast with a heavy body.  Thus was quite the tasty brew! Cheers!

Pours a dark brown color with a nice caramel colored foam head.  Has an aroma of smoked bacon, caramel, and pehaps some chocolate.  Has a sweet roasty barbecue taste with some bitter notes and some very subtle velvety chocolate notes on through the finish.

Bottle from Sun Devil.  Pours charcoal in color with a creamy brown head that leaves sticky lacing.  Smells of tree bark and toasted malt.  Tastes of sweet malt, cocoa, cream, and plum.  Good, but doesnt seem to style to me.

Pours thick, rich, nearly black with amber at the edges and smooth tan head.  Dark roasty aroma, smoky, chocolatey.  Taste is smooth and syrupy, like a mix of molasses and hersheys with some bitter notes for balance.  Finishes with a nice tang.  Great on a cold winter night.

bottle.  Pours completely opaque black, with bubbly small brown head.  Smoke characterizes the aroma, but faintly, with subtle notes of pork, barbecue, chocolate roast.  Mouth feel smooth, creamy, lightly carbonated.  Flavor is chocolatey, with some smoke on the finish, ash, pork.  Pretty nice brew, although I expected a little more.

Opaque black, lasting dense tan head, medium body, medium carbonation.

Aroma: black patent and chocolate malts, fireplace, hints of leafy hops and licorice and alcohol, and some smoked salmon.

Taste: black malts, somewhat acrid and astringent fireplace ashes, cola, and a hint of leafy hop bitterness.

More ash than smoke. Smoke is not nearly as up front or chewy as schlenkerla. More like they just stirred in a spoon-full of cinders.

Did I have a different Fade to Black?  Draft.  Pours black with a thin beige head.  Only the taddest bit smoky -- really quite lactic, creamy, with a bit of chocolate.  Very smooth and tasty.  Not a Baltic porter by any stretch -- no licorice, bitterness, not much smoke.

This beer casts a shadowy, light-less face, a dense black column supporting a rich khaki top.  Roasted coffee beans and dark chocolate dominate the aroma, light dried fruitiness and a soft astringency that may be linked to the dark malt.  An incredible chocolate and coffee smokiness blends with the weighty and silky feel.  A slight bite overtakes mid-palate, peaking at the finish into a bitter booziness that slowly recedes after the end.  The taste and mouthfeel yield a palate numbing sensation that accentuates the silkiness of the brew.  An incredibly well-crafted beer that excels on all fronts, from the unique taste to an exceptionally silky mouthfeel.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2011 I poured the bottle for a big head and got it (persistent, tan, creamy). The aroma was a bit antiseptic or like the bowels of a boat; not uncommon for this style especially if its well traveled. Couldnt be any darker.  Maybe that oil can beer from Colorado is darker.  Anyway...first impression is creamy followed by bready (in a good way) and just luxury all the effing way through.  WOW!  This is a gold medal caliber beer.  Not a light beer to be sure.  Its like the perfect loaf of hearty bread soaked in a diluted version of this beer.  You could stock this as an A+ mainstay in its category.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2011 On tap.
Pitch black color with a tan, mocha head.  First thing I smell is the smoky malts followed by sligh cocoa.  Very complex smokey flavor - roasted coffee as well.  Quite drinkable at nearly 8%, I enjoyed this one.

12 oz bottle. Pours black with rich tan head. Aroma of smoke, dark roasted grain, malt. Flavor is very smokey with rich dark roasted malt and some chocolate notes, light sweet. Mouth feel is medium-heavy body with medium carbonation. Overall, solid brew!

Poured from bottle.  Aroma of cherrywood smoke and bacon.  Porter black, a bit of tan head.  Roasted oat, cocoa, smoke and licorice in flavor.  Has stout qualities.  Very drinkable - excellent feel.  A great porter.
user_location: York, SC via NJ, South Carolina, USA

text:
A: The pour is a very dark brown color with a bit of amber in there too. A small khaki colored head goes with it.

S: Definitely smokey, but at least there are other things going on here. Some creamy vanilla and roasted malts along with a slightly sweet caramel note and maybe even a little bit nutty.

T: Again, its smokey, but not overwhelmingly so. Moderately sweet with some caramel, toffee, and a bit of creaminess. Theres a nice nutty flavor along with the roasted malts.

M: The body is medium with a somewhat low and smooth carbonation.

D: Not a bad smoked beer. Pretty well balanced with a lot of different flavors going on.

bottle - Pours black with a small, lingering tan head.  It smells of smoke and dark roast coffee accented malt.  The flavor is similar with plenty of smoke and coffee, a full body, and a moderately bitter finish.  Very enjoyable.

Pours jet black with thin brown head. Smells malty, like coffee and faint chocolate, and smoky. Tastes like smoked coffee, not too bitter, and faint sweetness. Full-bodied, smooth texture and faint mouth-carbonation, Left Hand Fade to Black (volume 2) finishes smooth and satisfying.

12oz draft at Smiths billiards Springfield MA.  I loved the smoky aroma and motor-oil color of this baltic porter.  Thin head stays around for a minute.  The flavors include chocolate, vanilla, and a hint of smoke in the finish.  The chocolate and alcohol dominate as the beer warms up a bit.  This was a perfect beer for a 10-degree New England night.

12 oz bottle. Very dark brown almost black with a thick, dense tan head. Aroma of mostly smoke with some light chocolate and vanilla. The flavor is semi-sweet chocolate with some acidic coffee and smooth and light bitter roasted malt. Full body with soft carbonation and a smooth mouth feel. Really great beer, smoky, chocolaty goodness and pretty drinkable.
12 Oz. Pours black with minimal head and an aroma of smoke and chocolate.  Taste comes on sweet and strong roasted malts with a strong bitterness to provide superb balance.  Easy drinking and crisp.

Nose of chocolate, roasted malts, hints of earth, and light barbecue sweetness in there as well. Pours dark brown with a nice creamy tan head and good lace. The flavor is chocolatey, roasty, earthy with moderate bitterness and light to medium sweet smokiness throughout. Medium body, nice drinkability. A solid effort.

Bottle. Pours a dark black oil color with no head. Smells of oak, smoke chocolate and tobacco. Tastes of BBQ, citrus, carmel and roasted nuts. Sort of tastes like a cross between a smoked beer and a stout, Kind of reminds me of Dogfish Heads Chicory Stout. Very good!

Bottle. Poured black in color with a large light brown frothy head that lasted throughout and had excellent lacing. The aroma was of  dark smoked  malts, an earthy yeast with notes of chocolate, caramel and coffee. It tasted a little acidic and slightly bitter with a smoke overtone in the beginning and finished with a little more of a bite with hints of chocolate, coffee and again a smoke overtone that was not heavy at all and stayed with you for an average lenghth of time. Mouthfeel was full in body and creamy in texture with a nice soft carbonation. Overall a nice tasty and quite drinkable smoked porter.

Near black and very thick looking, topped with a small brown head. The aroma was smokey, malty and a little nutty. The flavor begins lightly bitter and gradually increases as it finishes. It was medium bodied. This beer was pretty good, Id buy it again.

Draft at Chappys. Dark black pour with a fluffy tan head and good retention. Aroma is full of rich, smoked malts. Flavor is dry with dark chocolate, roasted malts, and moderate bitterness...all wrapped up with moderate smokiness. All around solid...pretty damn good.

In a 12 oz. bottle.  A great porter... but the name had me listening to metal all night, which annoyed my fiance.  Smell is dark roasted malt, a bit of coffee.  Taste had a dark chocolate/coffee thing going on for sure, not too fizzy.  Thick, but not too heavy.  I cant wait to finish the rest of them.

Charcoal and raisin aroma, hints of molasses. Opaque mahogany, thin brown head, good lacing. Smoked barley malt flavor with an obtrusive cane sugar sweetness that is very out of place. Far too sweet for the style.

12oz bottle. Dark black pour with a slight off brown bubbly head.  Good  amount of smoke in the aroma,  along with some bacon. Flavor has a bit of chocolate, but mostly smokey and woody. Not too heavy on the  palate. Enjoyable.

Wow.  This is great stuff.  Near black pour with ring of brown head, quick fading. Semi-smokey alcohol nose.  Flavor is more dry smoke, not bacon or hammy, but just strait smoke, with chocolate. Burnt roasty finish. Enjoyable now, but I imagine this could get better with a little age.

12oz bottle, bottled on 11/10/10.  Pours a dark brown black with a medium cream light brown head that slowly goes to a thin film that laces the glass.

The aroma is subdued - a little charred chocolate and liquid smoke.

The flavor is sweet lactic chocolate with some smoke and a weird plasticky hot (almost peppery) bitterness in the finish.  There is some warming alcohol present.  The mouthfeel is medium bodied with smooth carbonation.

Overall, its got some weird notes to it, but it kind of grew on me as I drank it.

On tap at the Gingerman Dallas. 

The beer pours a very dark brown to black color with a tan head. The aroma is heavy on the chocolate and caramel malt, with some nice smoked notes mixed in. The beer is smokey without being overwhelming. Very nice.

The flavor is more of the same. I get a nice amount of smoke in the flavor, but I also get some chocolate and roasted malt. There is also a slight amount of coffee in the flavor. The smoke is not as meaty as with a lot of the smoked beers I have tried - such as the Aecht Schlenkerla beers - but it is still very enjoyable. 

Medium to thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Very nice overall and a very good smoked beer for those that enjoy the style.

Aroma: Roasted malts very apparent.
Appearance: Black with a thick, tan head.
Taste: Medium sweetness, light sourness.
Palate: Medium-heavy body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, long finish.
Overall: Its a very solid beer, and something Id stock in my fridge, but not so outstanding that Im completely blown away.

Smooth and creamy, but still light on the palate, with well integrated smokey flavors. Lingering bitter malt and smoke finish. Compare this to other baltic porters (best ever!), rather than other smoked beers (too broad.) I do taste a good dose of dark fruitiness - burnt prune - not appropriate for the style, but it tastes great, so screw "style."
Pours black with thick black head. Strong smoke and mesquite aromas. Creamy almost milky palate with lots of smoke. Great for a winter day
Pours a black color with a tan head.  Aroma is of caramel malts, roasted malts, slight coffee, and chocolate.  Flavor is similar with a decent finish that lingers.  A pretty decent porter.

dark brown almost black pour with a thin but tight brown head.
aroma is quite smokey over chocolate malts.
flavour has a nice depth meaty and woody smoke. Cold coffee and lighter chocolate tones.
Light woody and bakers chocolate bitterness in the finish.

Bottle.

A - Cola brown/black with a creamy, good sized, thin meringue, fluffy, light cafe color. Really nice retention with a nice lace left.

S - Really nice and interesting aroma. Smoked meat and smokiness comes out first. Not super smoked meat aroma, but more balanced and smoked wood. Next whiff brings out some roasted coffee and a little bit of coffee and roasted malt. Hints of earthy and dark fruit aroma in the back.

T - Just like the nose, the flavor is a mix of smoked meat and wood and some roasted coffee and malt. The smoked wood flavor starts out the sip with it fading into more of a smoked meat. Not overly pork-like like some smoked meat flavors. Mid sip some more roasted coffee and malt along with some chocolate. Faint hints of tart dark fruit. Finishes with a slight tart flavor and faint hop bite. Slight bitterness on the finish.

M - Medium body with average carbonation. Pretty creamy fullish feel.

D - Nice beer to sip with a good balance between the smokiness and the porter flavors. Not one I would drink a lot of in a day but I would drink again.

Notes: Really nice balance between the smoked wood, smoked meat, and traditional porter flavors. Definitely has a smokey aspect, but that doesnt dominate the flavor. I enjoyed this beer quite a bit. Not amazing but quite good.

12oz bottled Nov 11, 2010.  Served at cellar temperature.  Pours medium black with a small brown head that quickly fades to a wispy cap and ring leaving some spots of lacing behind.  Aroma features some smoked malts, nothing too crazy but its there, some smoked meat and campfire, chocolate, coffee, dark fruits are there as well.  Picking up more smoke in the aroma than in the flavor.  Good strength.  Flavor features chocolate, coffee, anise, some dark fruits, smoked and roasted malts, some sweetness is there, just a hint of alcohol.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied if not a tad light, yet creamy, low to medium carbonation, pretty typical of a Baltic Porter.  Tasty stuff.  Moderately smoky, very drinkable Baltic Porter.

Big burnt mesquite smoked nose, almost sweet as it imparts a BBQ association.  Jet black, creamy mocha head, spotty lacing.  Rich dense smoky body, solid and direct.  Strongly smoky, but creamy in body and never gets sharp or piercing like some of the smokier offerings.  Love it.

Appearance- Almost black with a tan head that fades quickly.

Aroma- Very similar to what youd expect from a porter/stout with a touch of smoke added.

Taste- Up front it has the traditional porter/stout flavors but then you get the smoke as well as a bit of meatiness. The smoke is not nearly as assertive as I expected though.

Mouth-feel- Medium.

Drinkability- Goes down extremely smooth.

Bottle pours pitch black with chocolate tan head.  Aroma has that baltic porter twang nose, along with a touch of smoke and molasses.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavor is rich dense chocolate, a touch of smoke, roast, and finishes with a nice smooth fig or raisin chocolate flavor.  Excellent.

Bottle.  Pours super-dark red, black in the glass, with a small brown head.  Roasty cocoa aromas, light coffee, ice cream (lactose), and caramel.  The flavor is sweet chocolate and bitter grass, coffee, cocoa, smoky mocha, and latte (cream).  Medium body and carbonation, and creamy.  Quite tasty; a bit sweet, slightly bitter, and very smooth.

12 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet.  Pours very dark brown with a thin khaki head.  Aroma is of chocolatey malts with only hints of smoke and really gives no impressioin that this is anything other than a porter.  The flavor, on the other hand, does feature the smoked malt front and center.  Really well integrated smokiness with the typical dark chocolate and coffee found in a nice robust porter.  Not up to the same level as Alaskan Smoked Porter but a very nice and easier to obtain alternative.  Very well done.

On tap, dark reddish brown with lacy tan foam, aroma is roasty chocolate, flavor
is quite malty chocolate , roast caramel, well balanced smoke finish

12 oz bottle via 6-pack from Spirits Brick Blvd. Poured a dense dark black flat  body with a small to average sized tightly packed light beige foamy head. Aroma is obviously smoke but not so dominant that the great undertones of the base beer, Im thinking porter possibly stout, easily shine through. Remaining aroma of burnt toast, chocolate, dark fruits and a touch of burnt wood. Fuller bodied with carbonation so light its detectable just enough to keep one from thinking this one is flat. Flavor of smoked wood, burnt toast, bitter sweet dark bakers chocolate. Great beer but sadly last years FTB was better.
An intense porter if I ever had one. This beer has the most intense smokey flavor I have ever tried. Dark...

Bottle. Pours black with beige head. Nose has roast and chocolate, nice nutty, woody, and smokey quality rounds it out. Flavors have dark fruit-raisin and prune juice, a dirty earthy grain husky middle profile is off putting,  while sweet smoked meats finish and a tinny flavor sits on the palate. Medium body. Nice aroma but flavor is messy.

12oz bottle. Poured black with a short lived brown head. Aroma: Smoke, , coffee beans, roasted & burnt malts, sweet, some kind of dark fruit in there too. Taste carried out the nose but with some grain and a sharp bite in the finish. Medium body, good depth, some balance. Long finish. Overall this is a solid Smoked Porter: has a body and depth that makes it come off more like a Stout.

Bottle. Black bodied, but that goes without saying. Moderate, frothy brown head. Strong roasted malt and smoke in the nose. Burnt wood and dark, bittersweet chocolate as well. Taste is roasted malt, smoke, dark chocolate notes, coffee, burnt wood, and molasses. Body is medium-full with a mild, bubbly carbonation. Ends with more smoke, big roasted malt, cola notes, light coffee and thinned dark chocolate.

Bottle. Poured black color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate roasted malt aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy toasted bittersweet flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration. My expectations where met the second time.
From a bottle poured a dark brown color with a fair amount of head.  Nice smokey malty flavor with a lingering aftertaste.

Key Food, Flatbush Ave, Bklyn six-pack ($11): Black body with a rather brown head. Aroma is moderately smoky with plenty of roasted malts. Taste has plenty of smoke and a little bit of bite, but not from the alcohol. Lots of wood in the taste, but not as much as some other smokebeers. A tiny note of molasses laden sweetness, uncovering the Baltic porter lineage. Light roasty and burnt aftertaste follows. Easy drinking and fairly complex. I like it.
On tap at Taco Mac Kennesaw, great tan head, sweet aroma, a hint of smoke and bacon, its a bit sweeter than I expected, a lot like the GD Smoked Porter, and I quite enjoy it.

Purchased at Archer Liquors in Chicago, IL; enjoyed on New Years Day night watching the Winter Classic.  Appearance pitch black with a thin tan head, a very dark brown around the rim of the glass.  Aroma of smoked malts, lactose, smells creamy and delicious.  Taste has a fantastic balance of creaminess with the smoked malt, rich in coffee flavors with a hint of chocolate.  One of the previous ratings stated it was fudge-like and I agree, very decadent and awesome.  Highly recommended.

i cant believe they killed off that superman villain in the boat movie. .. Pours as black as a panther (peanut) .. . good head with medium strength lacing .. . roast, coffee, smoke, and bbq pit gunk in the nose; which follows smoothly into the mouth.. . damn drinkable, and no awareness of the abv! .. would love to try this on tap, but i know i never will .. . I will DEFINITELY be picking up some more before its all gone!! .. . you mean youre not my real parents!?!? -haha!! ya right!!

Pours oily black with a thin quick dissipating tan head.  Aroma is rasty malts, nuts, smokiness and chocolate.  Taste is smokey with caramel and nuts coming through.  The mouthfeel is thin, which makes this exceptionally easy to drink.
probably one of the best porters i have had. nice coffee and chocolate flavors, smoke comes through nice and not too strong. nice thick mouthfeel and a great slightly bitter finish. highly recommend

Bottle from Sams in Durham.  Pours dark, nearly black with a light mocha head.  Nose is light smoke and wood, coffee, chocolate, and that awesome Baltic quality that I dont have many words for.  Tastes more authentically Baltic than others, such as the great (but not necessarily true to form) Duck Rabbit Baltic.  The smoke is not too much; it lets the yummy porter come through.  This is very good, especially for the price.

aroma- smoke, licorice, dark malt, pipe tobacco.  pours brown/black with little brown head.  taste is heavy smoke, chocolate, bitter coffee, licorice, light sugar.  very balanced flavors!  palate is full bodied with lively carbonation, slightly creamy.
Pours dark black with a nice foamy, tan head. Taste is lots of chewy chocolate and molasses with a strong smoke presence. Very tasty. Nice amount of body in this beer.
I dont like smoke beers. This is completely smokey all around. Tastes like burned caramel. Smells like burned paper. All very acidic and smoky. Icky. Pair with mouthwash

(draught at Meddlesome Moth) near black, creamy dark tan head ad excellent lacing. Nose of smoke, rich fudge, cream, a bit of campfire but just enough. Taste of toasty raisins, light smokey fudge, cream, tons of rich flavors, also chocolate cake. Body is extremely rich, decadent, fudgey, creamy, and thick. Near perfect finish. A slight bit of salty briny flavors but a very small complaint. Awesome smoke beer and possibly the best Left Hand Ive had.

12 oz bottle poured into a Dimpled Mug at 46°.  Color is black with good carbonation and a creamy tight brown head.  Aroma of deeply roasted malt with a touch of smoke.  Medium bodied with a smooth mouth feel.  Flavor is slightly sweet with a little dark chocolate, then a mild smoke comes out with some coffee notes and a light bitterness.  After taste is a mild lingering bitterness and a creamy feel.  Overall its a very tasty and well balanced brew with a creamy palate.  Some have said that the smoke dominates, but I feel the smoke is mild and even, balancing nicely the other flavors.

12 oz. bottle. Bottled on 12/02/10. Pours a medium short lived mocha head, over a clear dark brown (SRM 40) body....nose is light smoke, lighter molasses, cereal......taste is light sweet to start, then smoke arrives, accompanied by a bit of plum, finishing with a light smoky bacon sweet bitterness....mouth feel is thick, and slightly sticky, carbonation adds a pleasant creamy sensation. This is a fairly typical Smoked beer. The smoke dominates, with sweet malt tones backing making for a simple but rich experience. This is a good winter beer. BJCP 7/3/14/4/7

12oz bottle. Poured a dark black. Big roasted, earthy aroma. Very smoky. Some malt and a little chocolate. Pretty good mouthfeel. Very strong smoke flavor. A little hops at the end. Since this is my first for the style, Ill probably rerate this at some point. Wasnt really great for me.

12 ounce bottle, bottled on 12/7/2010.  Served in a nonic pint glass, the beer pours dark brown/black with about an inch and a half tan head after an aggressive pour.  Head retention and lacing are both good.  Aroma is smoked and roasted malt and some chocolate.  The brew tastes like smoked malt, dark chocolate, roasted malt and a bit of coffee.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its creamy and a bit slick.  Drinkability is good, its smooth and goes down easy.  I think its a good overall brew, not a bad choice at all!

This pours a nearly opaque, cloudy garnet black. The head is small and rather short lived. Smoked and roasted malts make their showing in the nose in approximately equal proportions. The smoke is balanced and doesnt override the rest of the beer, which is nice. It implies a bit of oiliness in this otherwise medium bodied and  relatively dry beer. A bit of a guazy sort of medicinal character in the finish is my only real complaint. Otherwise, this is a really nice smoked beer.
Runny black. Thin head. Instantly refreshing. Dark, roasted malty nose. Smokey burnt malt flavor. Thin body. Fizzy bite on the finish.

the aroma is a pretty strong coffee with some dry chocolate, sweet malt and smoked aroma in there as well, it is black and not tranparent at all in my lager glass a tan thin head with some retention on the walls first flavor you feel some carbonatino then you get a smoked flavor and some chocolate then finishes with a coffee flavor, but the coffee is pleasent and in no way over powering overall a drinkable beer, but probably not gonna buy it again

Bottle.  Pours a clear brown to black with a thin to medium sized tan head.  Soft smoke and some wood and dark fruit.  Medium bodied, nice roast, softly warming alcohol with chocolate tones and chewy roast.  Subtle chocolate and warm gentle alcohol with some dark cherry hints.  Finishes slow and roasty with more warming alcohol and soft smoke.  Nicely done.

12 ounce bottle from Wine Warehouse in Charlottesville, VA. Pours a pitch black color with a thin offwhite head that sticks around the rim of the glass. Aroma of roasted malts, smoke, nutty notes and a faintly sweet finish. The taste is roasted malts, smoke, apples, nutty notes and a faint caramel finish along with some bitter hop notes. A little on the thin side, but its well balances and Im liking it quite a bit.

This starts with a nice roast and smokey aroma, with a hint of chocolate.  Pours an opaque black, with a tight cap of light tan head.  Very smooth roasted flavor, that finishes with a nice touch of smoke.  Clean on the palate, and very drinkable.  This is a good tasty beer for the winter months.
Excellent beer. Smoked cheese, coffee. A lot like the Smoke Jumper.  Or a Milk stout on steroids.

Thank you bro!  Pours deep brown with pale white head.  Very salty aroma similar to bacon (thanks andy).  Similar taste.  Tasted like smoked meat and malt.  Very tasty.  Wish I could remember volume 1 better, but I am very fond of this.

Bottle.  Pours black, near opaque with an average, frothy tan head, medium-long retention with fair to light lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (chocolate, roasted, nutty), light hops (earthy), and light esters (dried fruit) with notes of smoke, ash, prune, and wood.  Flavor is heavy malt (chocolate, coffee, roasted, nutty), light hops (earthy), and light esters (dried fruit) with notes of smoke, ash, prune, peat, and wood.  Full body, medium warmth, carbonation, and creaminess with a dry finish.

12 oz bottle purchased from Vino e Formaggio in Front Royal, VA.  Very black in the glass.  Light barely penetrate, but what light does penetrate it has a touch of red in it.  Deep dark chocolate flavors with a slight touch of smoke at the end.  Some sweet smoke aroma, reminiscent of Pinon wood followed by roasted espresso.  Overall, this is very good.  Ill have to get more...
Roasted malt aroma.   Taste is mostly malty, some smokiness, some hop presence hiding, definitely some alcohol.  Finish is quite bitter and smoky, maybe a bit bourbony.

Pours black with a thin beige head. Aroma is roast, light sweetness, and a little smoke. Flavor is sweet and chocolatey turning roasty and lightly bitter toward the finish with smokiness layered throughout.

Draft at Rich Os. Deep brown body, approaching black. Short, fizzy tan head with lots of lacing. The aroma is smokey, with notes of roasted malts, milk chocolate, cookie, resin. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. Medium body, watery texture turning velvety, thicker in the finish, average carbonation. This beer makes a good first impression. Its aroma is promising. After several ounces, however, its sweetness, especially in the finish, didnt work well with the smokey taste and the slightly metallic flavor. Not a deal breaker, but a disappointment.

Tasted from a 12 oz bottle purchased in Fort Collins, Colorado.  Pours a deep brown/black appearance with a weak dark brown head.  Dark burnt and particularly smoked malts in the head.  Quite smoky beer.  Theres the obvious burnt dark malts that hit you first and then the huge smoky flavor.  The smoky flavor is there on the finish and the aftertaste.  One of the best American smoked beers that comes to mind.  Highly recommended.

Bottle.  Pours a lovely shinny oily near black with a fine fizzy head.  At first you can smell some of that smoke but the hard roast dry chocolate cookie smell, reminiscent of last years, takes over.  Flavor follows the same, hard roast is slightly astringent, dry chocolate cookie, some light dark fruit, but again the roast over powers, dry with a long ashtray finish.  Medium bodied, carbonation is smaller but corse, lightly oily but leaves mouth with a dry ashy feeling.  Some really nice things in here, but some things I dont like as well.  The alcohol is very nice though!

Pours out pretty black with a dark tan head.  Aroma reminds me of damp wood, charcoal grilled ham, and earthy malts.  Interesting smell indeed.  But it doesnt quite work in the flavor.  The same damp wood and ham come into the flavor, as well as smokiness and charcoal.  Since it advertises itself as a porter I was hoping for some chocolate tones of any kind, and found none.  But, in its defense, it might be one of the best Smoked beers I ever tried.  Nicely balanced with malt and hop bitterness, and wonderful mouthfeel.  Im just not a fan of the overall taste.
Black with dark brown head.  Thick mouth feel with smoke and sweet malt flavor.

Appearance:  Pours a  dark brown with a creamy 1/8 inch cap of tan foam.

Aroma:  Smokey ham rind, liquid smoke, light roast.


Taste: Smoked ham, spicy roast, dark chocolate, coffee.


Mouthfeel: Medium bodied, moderate carbonation.


Overall:  Great levels of smokiness.

Pours very dark brown with light brown head. Aromas of roasted malts with a touch of smoke. Burnt malt flavor with a little sweetness and some smokiness. Not as much smoked flavor as I was hoping for. Medum body with moderate carbonation. A nice brew.

Black pour - mildly viscous - dark tan head - nice mix of roasted, black malts and smokey char in the nose - creamy mouthfeel - some sweetness cut with a moderate acidity up front - becomes moderately bitter through the middle - intensely roasty - never astringent, despite the bitterness and acidity - the smoke is not as forward as I would like, but it mixes nicely with the roast of the malt, and generates a nice warming campfire feeling - lingering char in the finish - nice balance - nice body - much better than the smoked baltic that Great Divide put out earlier this year, and for the price of a bomber of that, I can get a sixer of this - kudos, Left Hand.

Draft Pours black with a mid-sized, creamy, khaki head. Fantastic retention. Aromatic standouts are milk chocolate and smoked meat. Medium-bodied with prickly carbonation. The flavor is sweet, chocolaty and moderately bitter with a mild, smoky undertone. Finishes roasty and modestly bitter with a huge mocha component.

Dark brown/blackish pour, tan head.  Aroma of smoke, chocolate, oreos.  Light ashy bitterness, some meat.  Flavor is smokey with dark chocolate, medium to heavy bitterness,  umami.  Fairly strong alcohol.  Thick mouthfeel. Finishes bitter.  Pretty good.

the beer is a dark brown with garnet highlights and a fairly small, frothy, tan head which is mostly diminishing and does leave bits of froth on the glass.  The nose is smoked... smoked sausage, campfire, burnt chocolate, burnt toast, and faint roast.  Again the flavor is similar with smoked sausage, campfire, rich chocolate, light roast, burnt caramel, and a light pecan nutty note.  The palate is lively, round, velvety, and medium.  The finish is chocolatey, smokey, and drying.  I have tried an entire six-pack of this to see if the smoked notes will grow on me and I just cant finish an entire bottle.  I think the smoked sausage notes just turn me off from smoked beers.  Just too much smoke in this one for me.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2011 12oz bottle, consumed Feb 2011.
Pours deep dark brown, opaque, with a full milk chocolate head. Nose is chocolatey, roasty, and smoky. Medium body, silky, creamy, nice sweet stout sort of sweetness at first with a roasted, slightly smoked chocolate finish with mild to moderate bittering.  Really easy drinking, lots of flavor, a good, unique brew.

Bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown nearly black with a lasting brown head. Aromas of smoke, roasted malt, vanilla, drk chocolate and light licorice. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of smoke, roasted malt, bakers cocoa, light vanilla ans a hint of licorice with a smooth lingering smokey finish.

Pours black with nice carbonation and a medium tan head. Aroma has tons of roasted malt and a bit of smokiness. Likewise the flavor is smoky roasted malt with some cereal and slight lingering bitterness. The smoke is very present in the finish.

Black pour with no head.  Aroma was straight up roast, lots of malt, coffee, burnt toast and some smoke.  Flavors left a lingering smokiness in my mouth from top to bottom, roasted malts up front, spent coffee grounds, light bitterness.  Full mouth, light carbonation.  Not bad.
Black pour from bottle. Small head. Aroma of charred malt, light smoke, burnt marshmallow and alcohol. Flavor of smoke and burnt toast. Nutty, dry and bitter. Decent.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2010 12oz bottle.  wow...aroma of caramel, milk chocolate, a puff of smoke.  black under a small tan head.  flavor is smokey and quite bitter.  flavors of black, even burnt malts, black coffee.  dry, ashy finish.  solid, i just wish it was a little sweeter.
damn thats good stuff!  I had to change my rating after finishing the 6pack a few days later.  more.

Had on draft at Shakespears Pub in Kalamazoo, Mich.  I had to "settle" for this beer because they didnt have Shorts Cup-a-Joe.  I have to say, Im glad I missed out on Shorts tonight, because I got to have a go with this masterpiece.  This is a top-notch beer.  I wouldve had a second or third, had my wife not been nagging me to leave. Damn her.  Anyway, well done!

bottle.  pours a nice deep black out of the bottle with some lighter brown highlights and a 1 finger tan head, which falls in a couple minutes leaving a thin tan lacing.  wonderful nose - the smoke level is perfect... it is not over the top in any way... layers of deep cherry, caramel, currants and roasted malts linger through the smoked malts.  medium to full body with a very smooth and soft palate.  lots of dark fruits including raisins, red grapes, cherries and plums coat the mouth with a perfect smoke malt presence lingering up top and to the back.  a general sweetness persists throughout.  chocolate, coffee and smoked malts fill the back of the mouth through the finish.  This is an excellent beer from Left Hand!
